column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172075,2016,Contemporary Music History,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. P. Philipsen'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Knowledge of and insight into several musico-historical and musico-theoretical methods of research of recent decades as have been applied to art music of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries in particular; practicing academic reading and writing skills; reflecting on these skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course is part of the deepening package ‘Historical musicology’. The name of the course makes reference to ‘history’ both in the sense of ‘res gestae’ (the past) and in the sense of ‘historia rerum gestarum’ (historiography). The adjective ‘contemporary’ in its name, then, refers to either the music to be studied in this course (primarily art music of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries), or to the methods that are used to do so (methods ranging from hermeneutics to dodecaphonic theory). Participating students will obtain knowledge of and insight into all of this by means of ten case studies, for which they will both read and provide comments on several musicological publications as well as make a few musical analyses.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174859,2016,Contemporary Performance: Mapping The Everyday,English,University College Utrecht,,['R.C. Hinam', 'T.A. Vogel']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: Understand some of the ways in which everyday life may be used as a source for performance imagery.
Understand some of the demands, challenges and social responsibilities of the Community based, or Site-Specific Artist.
Utilize critical skills in analyzing the possible functions of the performing arts in contemporary society.
Understand how a specific site can be utilized as a synthesis of different disciplinary approaches.
Construct ways of approaching other sites and use them as a source for both creativity in general and performance making in particular
Enter into a creative relationship with the everyday.
Think ‘outside of the box’ (or auditorium) when approaching performance both as maker and as spectator.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Increasingly contemporary performance practitioners are leaving ‘the auditorium’ and working in a diverse range of locations not normally associated with theatricalisation and performativity. This may involve working with a specific community of people or in a specific geographical location, or a combination of the two. There are many reasons for this trend which we shall explore both in practice and in theory.

Using a site as a starting point for performance making allows for a multi-disciplinary approach. The site of the UCU campus, given it’s history, is immediately interesting for people concerned with, for example, religious studies, gender studies, geography and in military history. It is, in it’s present day incarnation, a subject of much interest to anthropologists and educationalists. Our immediate neighbours are the Dutch army which connects us, inextricably, with the world of politics. It is anything but an empty stage !

On the UCU campus the primary ‘actors’ can be, economically speaking, divided between those that pay to be on the campus and those that are paid to be there. Both groups have significantly different perspectives on campus life, but each have their stories to tell. You will be involved with the people that work on campus. You will have the opportunity to get to know the campus from a unique perspective, as performance makers/researchers, interned, if you like, in your own everyday. From that everyday experience we will look at the notion of ‘free speech’ and the very real ethical and moral dilemmas this brings with it. We will look in a broad sense at how stories are told in the postmodern world.
We will be researching the everyday, the yesterday and remediating our research into some sort of performative ‘present’ at the end of week 4 of the autumn semester.

This is an intensive course.  It starts on the Monday two weeks before the start of the autumn semester. Participating students have to be free from 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday for these two weeks before the semester starts.  During these two weeks we will establish a time-table for the rest of the course, which will take into account the other courses students will be following. This will mean we may well be working in the evenings and weekends outside of the normal college time-table. So prospective students need to be both flexible and committed.

The course is automatically open to all students who have completed both a 2 Level 1 and Level 2 course within the Performng Arts track. Other students will be considered, especially if they have significant practical experience and a genuine interest in performance and medial processes that happen outside of the auditorium.

A course like this can only work if the group spirit is right and participants are willing to pull their own weight. It therefore requires a high level of maturity, sense of responsibility, a willingness to engage with others, and an essential openness to exploring new and old ground.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173415,2016,Contemporary Performance: Mapping the Field,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. L.W. Groot Nibbelink'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Students learn to compose and write a contextual analysis, based on the conceptual frameworks introduced in the course.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Contemporary Performance – Mapping the Field aims to investigate and map the field of contemporary (European) theatre, dance and performance. The course explores recent trends and topics in the field of European theatre, dance and performance, with a focus on what we will name a performative, a social and a spatial turn.

We will discuss and query what are relevant concepts, sources and discourses to engage with current societal, political and aesthetic developments, and investigate how we can use these to contextualise contemporary performance. Students learn to compose and write a contextual analysis, which addresses relations between emerging artistic practices, dramaturgical strategies, social worlds and cultural debates. They learn how to connect this to conceptual frameworks by which these issues can be described, interpreted and critically reflected on and discussed. Visits to performances, festivals and other events are a constitutive part of this course.
This course can be taken, if approved by the course coordinator, as a 7.5EC course by students started in 2014-2015 or earlier.

The course includes active visits to performance festivals and meeting with practitioners and programmers; students learn to recognize and analyse forms of contextual analysis in professional practices.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170916,2016,Contemporary approaches in anthropological theory,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. A.C.G.M. Robben'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Advanced knowledge of the principal theoretical currents in the history of cultural anthropology.

column5: In-depth knowledge of contemporary theory building about culture, agency, power, practice, meaning, and flows.
Thorough understanding of the epistemological implications of recent theoretical developments.
Awareness of the methodological consequences of current theoretical debates for empirical research.
Reflection on the relation between theory and data.
Development of oral presentation skills and the chairing of seminar discussion.
Development of academic writing and research skills through two critical essays on the readings and one major final essay.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course provides an advanced examination of the principal contemporary anthropological theories with close attention to their epistemological assumptions and methodological implications for research. Anthropological theory arose at the beginning of the 20th century when ethnographers tried to apply the social theories of Spencer, Marx, and Durkheim to non Western societies. The evolutionism of 19th century anthropologists such as Morgan and Tylor was discarded, and functionalism with its emphasis on enduring cultures and social structures became the dominant paradigm propagated by Boas, Kroeber, Malinowski, and Radcliffe-Brown. This paradigm became replaced between the 1950s and 1970s by the structuralism of Lévi-Strauss, Marxist anthropology by Eric Wolf, and symbolic anthropology by Clifford Geertz. Their theoretical legacy consists of an enduring attention to meaning and power. Bourdieu added a concern for practice and agency by his theoretical answer to the structure-actor opposition. Globalization has raised these key anthropological concepts meaning, power, practice, and agency to a new level of complexity by subjecting them to worldwide flows of people, goods, information, and knowledge.  Schedule An effort is made to schedule seminars on Mondays. For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual.  Commitment: Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:
•         80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
•         Handing in papers and assignments on time; and

Overdue papers are downgraded with a one point per day penalty. There exists no collective possibility to resubmit rewritten papers. Only students who have complied with all commitment policy requirements will be given one additional chance to submit a rewritten paper within three weeks after the course ended. Resubmission is not a right of students but a privilege given by the course coordinator on a case-to-case basis, and therefore require his permission.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173141,2016,Content and Language Integrated Learning,English,Graduate School of Teaching,,['drs. G.J. Koopman', 'M.I. Decovsky']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course module you will have attained
- knowledge and skills in the following key points for CLIL:

column2: • Adapt and sequence resources, teaching and learning activities

column1: - knowledge of Dutch policy toward TTO education and you will be able to put this in an international perspective
- knowledge and understanding of the role of English departments at Dutch TTO schools.
Additionally, by the end of the course you will have acquired the following academic skills:

column2: • Critical analysis of scientific, policy and popular texts on Content and Language integrating Learning;

column1: To enable students to exhibit competences a set of take home assignments has to submitted. The evaluation in this course consists of these four assignments, each contributing to the final mark. To have the course marked as completed in Osiris, each assignment needs to be assessed satisfactory (grade ≥ 5.5).  Satisfactory contribution plus presentation of the final assignment during the sessions is a condition for the assessment tasks to be assessed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Content and Integrated Language module of Uteach aims to prepare the student teachers (both subject teachers and teachers of English) to teach and function professionally and effectively at  schools for ‘Tweetalig Onderwijs’  in the Netherlands.

The course focuses both on theories related to teaching your subject through English and various models how to achieve this. You learn about how learners learn languages and how you can facilitate this in your subject lessons. How is teaching biology or history through English different from teaching it in the learners' first language? Which skills do you need to develop to facilitate learning of both your subject and English? How can you give feedback to learners on both content and language?
In the course you will design, practise at your school and evaluate learning actitivies related to CLIL.
Moreover, will you gain insight into the specifics of the Dutch TTO situation.
In the course the  following formats will be used:
Blended learning, Workshop, Individual assignments (designing and executing lesson, Group assignments, Presentations, Peer Evaluation and feedback, Editorial Review, Online Interaction, Self Study.
Before each workshop session chapter or articles need to be studied and or observation tasks need to be carried out.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173074,2016,Continuum Mechanics and Rheology of the Crust and Mantle,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['prof. dr. C.J. Spiers', 'prof. dr. W. Spakman']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course introduces students to the mathematical foundation and rock mechanics background needed to understand the deformation behaviour of the crust and mantle at the macroscopic, mesoscopic and microscopic scales. The course is primarily designed for students interested in structural geology, geophysics, crust/lithosphere/mantle and Earth materials studies, or planning to embark on the Master Programme in Earth Structure and Dynamics. However, it will also be valuable to students interested in transport, flow and/or Earth material properties in the context of geochemistry, sedimentology, petroleum geology, geotechnical engineering, hydrogeology, meteorology and oceanography.
The course aims to provide students with:

column5: The fundamentals and definitions of stress and (incremental) strain(rate)
A basis in the physical equations describing the mechanics of continuous media (fluids, solids), including the laws of conservation of mass and momentum

An understanding of how the mechanical behaviour of materials can be specified phenomenologically in terms of stress-strain(rate) relations or constitutive equations, and how these can be used to describe elastic deformation, viscous flow and solid state flow.

A quantitative understanding of the mechanical behaviour (constitutive equations and failure criteria) of real rock materials in the crust and mantle, and of the processes that control this behaviour.
The ability to attach physical meaning to geological structures and to formulate hypotheses about the responsible processes.

The ability to apply the principles learned to modelling simple problems in tectonics, geodynamics and crustal geomechanics (e.g. enhanced hydrocarbons production and CO2 storage), and to report (team) results in a systematic manner.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course introduces students to the mathematical foundation and rock mechanics background needed to understand the deformation behaviour of the crust and upper mantle at the macroscopic, mesoscopic and microscopic scales.

column2: • Stress and deformation: mathematical basis, tensorial description, equilibrium equation, symmetry of stress tensor representations of stress (principal stress, stress ellipsoid, Mohr’s circle)
• Deformation, displacement gradient tensor, strain- and rotation tensor. Conservation laws: material derivatives, mass balance (continuity equation), momentum conservation
• Intro to constitutive equations; linear elasticity for isotropic media, elasto-dynamic equation for seismic waves
• Hydrostatic fluids, linear viscosity, Navier-Stokes equation; Course summary

column1: This part will be thought in Dutch if no foreign students are in the class.

column2: • Rheology and deformation processes in rocks - rock behavior in nature and experiment, relationship with continuum mechanics.
• Elastic behaviour of rock: atomic scale basis, elastic constants, iso- vs. anisotropic behaviour, poroelasticity of reservoir rocks.
• Brittle/frictional behaviour: fracture, faulting and mechanical effects of pore fluid pressure.
• Ductile Deformation: crystal defects, plastic and diffusional flow, constitutive equations, deformation maps, recrystallization, generalising 1-D flow laws to 3-D

column1: Mechanical behaviour of the crust and upper mantle: lithosphere strength profiles for continental, oceanic and fault zone scenarios.

column2: • The final grade for the course is calculated as follows. Mid term exam Spakman (Continuum 50%) + end term exam Spiers (Rheology 50%) = 100% of final grade (both parts count equally towards the final grade).
• Practicals/tutorials/homework: Continuously assessed on a pass/fail basis.
• All Practicals/tutorials & homeworks must be completed with a “pass” to complete the course.

• The minimum pass grade (average of Part 1 Spakman and Part 2 Spiers) for the course is 5.5 out of 10, with all assignments completed. Grades between 5.50 and 5.99 are rounded up to 6.0. A grade of 5.49 or less is a fail. The right to a repair examination is granted  only if the unrounded average grade for Parts 1 and 2 lies between 4.00 and 5.49 and if the student has completed and obtained a pass for all assignments. A grade of 3.99 does not entitle a student to a repair examination. Repair exams may address Part 1 (Continuum) or Part 2 (Rheology) – students may choose which they prefer to resit (one only). After the repair exam, the final course grade is calculated as the average of the grades obtained for Parts 1 and 2, with the repaired grade updated. If the course grade obtained is 5.50 or above it will be set at 6.0, i.e. no final scores higher than 6.0 are given following a repair exam. If the final grade is < 5.49, the result is a fail and entire course has be redone, if a pass is sought.

• The right to a repair exam is not automatic if ill.  De-registering for an exam or test due to illness does not automatically entitle students to take a repair test or exam.  After recovery, the student must supply a doctor’s note certifying that the student was ill on the day of the test/exam.  Without this, students have no right to a repair exam.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174964,2016,Core Research Seminar Medieval Literature,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['Docent nog onbekend/To be announced'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing the course the participants:
- have knowledge about the dominant modern approaches to medieval literature and about their merits and weaknesses
- have knowledge about the major genres in the European medieval literature and have read at least one text from each genre
- are able to determine which approach is followed in modern studies about medieval literature and to judge the quality of those studies
- are able to choose an approach which is fitting to answer a specific question about one or more specific medieval literary texts.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The modern concept 'literature' did not exist in the middle ages. This implies that when modern scholars talk about medieval literature, they are using an anachronistical term. There are several ways to cope with this problem. In this course the advantages and the disadvantages of the various approaches wil be discussed and demonstrated by confronting medieval texts with modern scholarship.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174269,2016,Core Research Seminar: Art History II,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. H. Bavelaar', 'dr. V.M. Schmidt', 'prof. dr. M.A. Weststeijn']",,"Course goals

column3: To study fundamental and recurring themes in art and the historiography of art from the middle ages to the modern period.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The seminar will be a devoted to one or more fundamental and recurring themes in art and the historiography of art from the middle ages to the modern period, with special reference to the Low Countries. This year, the theme will be art of the Low Countries in a global perspective, with special reference to the artistic exchange with Italy during the 15th-17th centuries; Dutch art at the time of the maritime expansion (17th-19th centuries); and the global art world of the 20th-21st centuries.</body>

column3: Using material evidence provided by Roman history, this course focusses on recent trends and methodologies in the study of the ancient Roman world, with special emphasis on how, in this particular field, questions are typically framed, on the way methodologies are employed, and on how results are reached. Students acquire a good working knowledge of the current topics and approaches in Roman history and learn how to position themselves vis-a-vis these developments.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174265,2016,Core Research Seminar: Art History I,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. M.A. Weststeijn', 'prof. dr. S.G.M. Dupré']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: To study fundamental and recurring themes in art and the historiography of art from the middle ages to the modern period.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This year, the general theme will be “art and knowledge”. The first part of the course also forms part of the Technical Art History programme of the University of Amsterdam, and will be coordinated by Sven Dupré. The focus of this part of the course will be Light, Color and Perspective in Art.

The application of linear perspective in early fifteenth-century Italian painting is considered a defining moment in the history of art. The seminar re-examines the historiography of perspective developed since Erwin Panofsky’s ‘Perspective as Symbolic Form’. On the basis of the analysis of works of art and contemporaneous writings we study perspective as practice (instead of symbolic form). The seminar also broadens the scope of investigation towards the study of color, light and shadow, which have only more recently gained sustained attention, opening up connections to technical art history. One of the central question we are concerned with is whether and in which ways the practice of perspective, light and color in the arts is related to bodies of optical, mathematical and philosophical knowledge.
The second part of the course will be coordinated by Thijs Weststeijn, and will consider broader issues in the relation between art and knowledgde.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174402,2016,Core Theories and Current Debates,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. A. Rigney'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Knowledge of the most important theoretical approaches and concepts in the field of comparative literature as well as current research and debates; ability to apply theoretical insights critically to particular cases, and to situate ongoing debates within their historical context.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces students to the core theories and approaches of Comparative Literature and examines the most important on-going debates within the field. As such, it provides a foundation for the more specialized courses that follow. An emphasis is placed on the question of comparison as a method and as an object of study: in short, what is the comparative in Comparative Literature and how is it studied? What are the theoretical, methodological, practical, ethical and political implications of comparison? The course will situate current and ongoing debates within the field in their historical context.
This course serves as preparation for a PhD program in the humanities as well as non-academic careers paths by training students in the following transferable skills:
Academic and critical thinking and writing, discourse analysis, communication skills, presentation skills, peer review, advanced language skills.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Institutions shape human lives and human history. Without rules and organizations, societies disintegrate and the results are usually terrifying (think of Syria today). In this course, we want to understand how institutions emerge and evolve – historically. In general, social scientists have reflected on this topic more systematically than historians. Some of these social scientists have used historical data to underpin their theories. The aim of this course is to get to know some of those theories, and at the same time familiarize ourselves with the way social scientists think, and the vocabulary they use to frame their ideas.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174648,2016,Core themes and modern classics 1: Public administration,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. T. Schillemans', 'prof. dr. M.J. Trappenburg']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: gain extensive knowledge and insights with regard to important themes in the intersection between public administration and political science:governing and being governed, the shift from government to governance, and the effectuation of policy reform. Students are able to digest and discuss three important books in the discipline related to the three selected themes;
can comprehend and evaluate recent dissertations, relating them to the core themes of this seminar (governing and being governed, the move from government to governance and policy reform),);
are able to identify and discuss theoretical angles, methods of research, research findings and policy consequences;
can write a review of a dissertation, taking into account the standards of an academic journal.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This seminar centers around three key themes that connect the worlds of political science and public administration. During the first part of the course, you read three important books related to these three core themes. The books will be discussed in seminar-style sessions.
During the second part of the course, you will read three dissertations, related to each of the three core themes. The authors of the three books will be our guests.
This seminar is highly interactive. You will be divided in groups, which will practice academic competences relevant for an informed, academic discussion:

column5: Chair the discussion;
Rehearse the line of argument in the book, and defend the author against criticisms raised by the group;

Be a discussant. Discuss, and if necessary, criticize research methods employed in the book, discuss the theoretical perspectives, comment on the research design, discover possible flaws in the book, compare the book with other books. Discuss directions for future research inspired by the book, comment on the findings, and reflect on policy consequences.

column3: During the second part of the course you will also learn how to write a book review. You first write a draft review about one of the dissertations. The teachers will write comments on the draft review so as to improve your writing skills. The rewritten draft reviews will be graded. In addition you will write a book review on one of the other dissertations.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174593,2016,Core themes and modern classics 2: Public organizations and professionals,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['Externe docent', 'prof. dr. L.G. Tummers']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: become familiar with the core themes of management and organization theory in the public sector, on a macro- level, a meso-level and on a micro-level;

obtain knowledge about the distinctiveness features of public organizations and how professionals operate within these contexts and to integrate this knowledge with more general organizational and managerial insights;
integrate theoretical and empirical insights into a research question, theoretical framework and methodology to study public organizations at a macro-, meso- and micro-level;
reflect on the process of knowledge creation within the broader subfield of organization and management of public organizations an assess implications for their own research.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Core themes and modern classics 2 studies public management and organizational science by analyzing the role of public organizations and the public professionals working within these organizations. Hence, while core themes 1 focused on broad public governance and policy issues, core themes 2 dives deeper into the distinctiveness of public organizations (macro-level), element in individual organizations (meso-level) and the way professionals/employees in these organizations interact with among else citizens (micro-level). It is composed of three related parts (macro, meso and micro). These parts are strongly connected, as will also be discussed during the course. In all these parts, the publicness aspect is always an issue, even when discussing the topics that are generally considered to be less contextual (such as organizational behavior).

column4: The first part of the course analyses the classic and contemporary work on Public Organizations and their distinctiveness. This involves both formal (organizational structure) and less formal distinctions (strategic management) at the organizational or macro-level. Topics that are discussed concern publicness and the value of bureaucracy. In order to so, Weber and his classical treatise of bureaucracy will be confronted with more recent perspectives. Also, the mechanisms behind this distinctiveness will be treated within the course of this part, in particular institutional theory (both continuity and change) – linking back institutional values and logics of the previous point – and the effect of culture and climate. The macro-level discussion will be concluded with a discussion on strategic management in the public sector.

column3: The second part of the course will address the meso-level, elements that can be found within individual organizations. Strategic human resources literature will be used as a linking pin between the macro and the meso-level. Next to this, leadership and its outcomes in terms of relationships will be discussed. While the former is often framed in a positive way, also concepts having a more negative connotation (and consequent effect on organizational outcomes) will be discussed. It particular, we will address the idea of red tape (the ‘formal approach’), as well as the idea of organizational politics (‘the informal approach’). It is self-evident that in these sessions, we will refer back to the knowledge generated from the first part, but that we as well look ahead to the more individual concepts of the third part, as this meso-level provide a linking pin between the macro- and the micro level.

The third part of the course will address individual characteristics and processes that are crucial for understanding how organizations operate. Again, these will build on previously touched-up issues and they will be clearly embedded within the context the public sector in a broad sense. A first topic is framed in a more positive way as it is mostly linked to preferable outcomes. This topic concerns motivation of public employees. Topics like self-determination theory and public service motivation will be treated here. Next to this, also more negative aspects of individuals within organizations are discussed. These concern policy alienation and individual coping strategies and consequent outcomes. Within the framework of the micro-level part, a balanced approach to outcomes is discussed. This refers to the idea that outcomes of organizations at the individual level should be equally divided between organizational benefits (various type of individual performance and other outcomes) and employee outcomes (job satisfaction, reduced stress and burnout level and general increased well-being). Furthermore, we will discuss how professionals interact with citizens, and the role of race and discretion herein.
The literature will be discussed in plenary sessions. In these sessions, a lecture by professors or guest will provide an overview and will go deeper into the specific elements of the literature.

Students will be actively involved, via presentations, ‘serious games’ and debates. You will deliver three group assignments (in groups of three students), all addressing particular elements of a research proposal (1: introduction and research question, 2: theoretical framework and 3. research design/methodology). You will also deliver one individual assignment (a research proposal on a core macro/meso and/or micro topic regarding public organizations and professionals).

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175184,2016,Core themes and modern classics 3: Transforming public governance,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • are familiar with social changes and their impact on the transformation of public governance and organization;
• are familiar with the main theories that are used by governance scholars to study social change and related transformations in governance;
• learnt to appreciate the value of these theories as analytical tools for understanding the impact of social changes on public governance;
• have a practical understanding of how public, but also private organisations cope with social changes through the transformation of policy making and governance;
• be able to critically analyse the implications of broad social changes on the public sector.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Broad social shifts occur that can be grasped as a shift from modernity to late modernity. These changes challenge existing values and organisational arrangements and have a fundamental impact on how decision-making and policy implementation is organized and how organizations function.

We start this course by introducing an important argument by Robert Putnam. In ‘Bowling Alone’ Putnam argued that the depth and extent of social capital has declined. These social changes have an impact upon government and democratic institutions. Similar changes occur in organizations involved in government and in the inter-organizational relations between government actors. Giddens and other sociologists have argued that a shift occurs from ‘modernity’ to ‘late modernity.’ In late modernity, the balance between actors and institutions changes. A ‘new risk society’ emerges in which risk is no longer exogenous, but instead ‘manufactured.’ This shift has strong implications for policy, governance and the organization of policy implementation. In all these domains, we observe a a growing emphasis upon ‘activation’ and ‘responsabilisation.’ The allocation of responsibilities changes. Responsibilities are increasingly shared between government and other actors and also the nature of intra- and inter-organizational relations changes. In response to that, a large number of new ideas on governance and organization emerge in the public administration and organization literature, including e.g. Osborne’s New Public Governance. We also see a strong proliferation of these themes in Dutch universities.

​In this course, we will be discussing the relation between social changes and changes in governance. The ideas on these transformations of the public sector are not without debate, however. Jessop, e.g., considers them rather naïve and Byrkjeflot and Du Gay consider them undesirable. We will also be discussing the debate that occurs in the literature.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The prerequisite for this course is that the student has completed at least one of the following courses:
This course cannot be combined with the course Entrepreneurship, Innovation and Technology (LUISS Guido Carli).

In the quest for sustainable competitive advantage, companies are increasingly finding that lower costs, higher quality and better customer service are not enough. In times of increasing globalization and tremendous market and technological change, they must be faster, more flexible, more aggressive and more innovative in order to maintain their competitive edge – in short, they must be more entrepreneurial.

Entrepreneurial processes are not limited to the domain of independent new ventures, increasingly also being recognized as essential to the long-term viability of existing organizations. Corporate entrepreneurship (CE, often also referred to as intrapreneurship) involves the study of entrepreneurial processes and principles as applied in established organizations. It denotes the ability to stimulate the attributes of the small enterprise into the large, established organization, i.e. to import the logic of individual entrepreneurship and the entrepreneurial spirit. CE characterizes a new management philosophy that promotes strategic agility, flexibility, creativity, and continuous innovation with the aim of transforming administrative-oriented employees into “intrapreneurs”.

This course explores the practices and challenges involved when established companies initiate CE. It reviews how companies can rely on strategic innovation to reinvigorate and renew themselves, their markets, or their industries. As the link between innovation, entrepreneurship and strategic growth has become centrally proclaimed and emphasized, this course is further designed to provide the student with a basic understanding of how innovative activities of a company are managed. Since new products based on innovation in a Schumpeterian sense are essential for growth and increased profitability, companies must manage these activities.

The course deals with both the conceptual and practical meaning of CE. Several theoretical perspectives will be introduced, emphasizing both the capabilities for CE and the constraints working against entrepreneurial behavior. The course is characterized by a multidisciplinary approach and combines insights from economics, entrepreneurship research, sociology, psychology, and strategic management.

column2: • Building blocks of CE (e.g. definition, differences between CE and independent entrepreneurship, forms of CE, process of CE);
• Degree and frequency of entrepreneurship in organizations (i.e. entrepreneurial intensity);

• Creating an entrepreneurial organization (e.g. HRM, personality traits of corporate entrepreneurs, motivations for entrepreneurial behavior, strategic entrepreneurship, elements and development of an entrepreneurial culture).

column1: This course will give the student an understanding of the concept of CE, including corporate venturing, innovation, transformation, rejuvenation, and strategic renewal, as well as mindsets and tools to foster CE in practice.
At the end of the course the student is better able to:

column2: • Understand the different meanings and implications of CE;
• Explain and discuss the core theories and models within the field of CE;
• Apply these theories and models in practice (i.e. to the operations of existing companies);
• Measure CE at different levels of established organizations;
• Judge organizational characteristics and processes on how much they enable or constrain CE;
• Identify ways to overcome obstacles to CE;

column1: There will be plenary lectures and plenary tutorials.
The main focus of the lectures is on knowledge transfer and creating an understanding for the subject.

In plenary tutorials, assignments and typical exam questions will be worked out together so that you are well prepared for the upcoming weekly quiz and the final exam. The main focus of the tutorials is to get you to work, to work through exercises together, and to have more time for your questions.

The final course grade will be the weighted average of your best three weekly quiz grades (together 15% weight) and a final exam (85% weight). There will be six weekly quizzes. The best three grades of your weekly quizzes will count for 5% of your course grade (together 15%). The weekly quizzes will consist of calculus.

The weekly quizzes will be online assignments on 'Connect'. This is an online learning and testing environment of the publisher of the textbook, McGraw-Hill. To access Connect you need the unique login code from your textbook. It is your responsibility to have access to the online environment on which the weekly quizz will be offered and that you have a reliable and working internet connection for the weekly quiz. You do not need to pass the weekly quizzes in order to pass the whole course.

To minimize cheating all questions in the weekly exercises will be unique. Each student will get a random draw out of a pool of questions about the same topic and all calculus questions will be algorithmic. Moreover the time frame in which the weekly quiz can be answered will be limited to reduce the opportunities for cooperation.

There is no opportunity to retake individual weekly quizzes or all weekly quizzes altogether. As only the best three quizzes are taken into account for the course grade you can miss some weekly quizzes without endangering your course grade. If you cannot take a weekly quiz or two, for example because of sickness, then there are still enough other weekly quizzes left to get a good grade. You can miss up to three weekly quizzes, provided you do the other three. If you only hand in two weekly quizzes, then the grade of the two you handed in will be counted with 5% each plus  one (missing) quiz with grade 1 for 5%. If you hand in only one weekly quiz, then two missing quizzes (5% each) will be counted with grade 1. If you hand in no weekly quiz, 15% of your course grade will be a 1.

Make sure that you hand in 3 weekly quizzes as early as possible. It is your responsibility if you get sick late in the course and you speculated on handing in only the last three weekly assignments. There will be no retake opportunity for the weekly quizzes! If you cannot attend an exam, e.g., because you are sick, then you need to contact the exam commission

The final exam is a closed-book exam which consists of multiple choice questions and open calculus questions. The final exam will cover all topics of the course, including the topics of the weekly quizzes. This is not an online exam and you are not allowed to bring any books or notes to the final exam. Only non-programmable calculators are allowed. A sheet with the most important formulas will also be provided (and posted in advance of the exam on BB). The exam will consist of 35 multiple choice and a multiple open questions.

There will be no effort requirement for this course, so following U.S.E. policy, a 4 means you are eligible for a full retake and a 5 means you can choose between a full retake or a supplementary retake.
Please purchase the following course textbook before the first lecture:
Hillier, Clacher, Ross, Westerfield, Jordan (2014): Fundamentals of Corporate Finance, 2nd European Edition, McGraw-Hill, ISBN-9780077164263

Make sure that you buy the European edition of the textbook and not the American one (simply check the ISBN number to be sure). And make sure you buy the book at ECU’92 for obtaining the connect-code (essential for the course).
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172408,2016,Corporate Governance,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['prof. dr. E.J.J. Schenk'],,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course puts at centre stage the way in which corporate governance regimes (and codes) have developed differently across countries and now seem to be converging. Yet, and despite the ongoing globalisation of big businesses as well as financial markets, large firms still have to cope with transaction counter-parties who operate within different legal and political systems, and who rank social priorities quite differently. One focus of the course, therefore, is on the role of institutions in corporate governance, including systems of employee co-determination. Another focus is on the corporate governance issues that are at stake in (cross-border) mergers and acquisitions (e.g. the EC takeover regulation). Since recent experience would suggest that executives of large firms might play a trick on both shareholders and the wider economy, despite elaborate mechanisms that have been designed to prevent this, the course also spends some time on the problems of incentives, i.e. on determinants and methods of executive compensation. This rather naturally leads to discussions of business ethics and corporate social responsibility. Finally, the course covers issues of corporate communication with capital markets, including issues such as corporate disclosure (predominantly—but not exclusively—in the domain of finance, e.g. with respect to quarterly statements) and insider trading.
At the end of the course the student should be able to:

column2: • Approach corporate governance issues in international business with a sound mixture of detachment and involvement;
• Pursue academic research that aims at furthering the development of studies in corporate governance;
• Solve topical problems in international corporate governance while taking into account both the particular nature of large firm decision making, the interests of stakeholders and the social fabric;
• Actively take part in topical debates on corporate governance;
• Advise governments as well as business firms on the implications of particular forms of corporate governance.

column1: The format consists of seminar classes and possibly a few guest lectures, and consulting classes during which students can approach the professor for elucidation on, and clarification of, course materials.

The group of course participants is divided into subgroups that should alternately support or reject an important message/hypothesis presented in the course’s literature. This should be done on the basis of literature that is not covered in class, selected by the groups, and okayed by the professor. Since this work requires collaboration among the students within a group, they are expected to have (at least) one meeting per week. The groups should prepare minutes of their meetings which will have to be submitted to the professor for approval. Meetings should take place during the slots that have been reserved for the consulting classes. The performance of the groups and the individuals within these groups is graded (see below).

The literature that has been selected for support or rejection arguments must be submitted for the exam. On average, this literature should amount to approx. 150 pages (this would be similar to approx. 10 papers from relevant journals).

Students are required to write two term papers, one detailing the collapse of a particular corporation or the threats to its survival from a corporate governance viewpoint (e.g. Enron, Parmalat, Ahold), another containing an assessment of factual corporate governance structures of three corporations (one from the Netherlands or Germany, one from France or the UK, one from the US) anno 2015. These papers should be written by teams consisting of three students but exceptions to this rule are possible after consultations with your professor. The firms will be assigned by the professor and/or lecturer from the Fortune Global 500.
The course grade will be a composite of grades given for term papers and active class participation (40%) and final exam (60%).

The exam will not just test whether you have studied the assignments but will also ask ‘tough’ questions of understanding. This may mean that you will be confronted with quotations from the literature that you will have to explain in the exam.

Students who fail the course may be granted a resit for the exam on the self-proposed literature or the term paper (notice that the result on the resit, together with the paper must be high enough to get a passing grade for the course when averaged with the class performance grade). The number of possible resits is limited by common U.S.E.-regulations.

Furthermore, they will be challenged to find information about applicable regulations and data regarding companies. Finally, the students will be requested to write a paper and present the results of an assessment in respect of a multinational company’s corporate social responsibility policy.
The course provides for a series of lectures and tutorials.

column3: This course aims to increase knowledge of and insight into current disourse of corporeal literacy, as well as into the strategic potential of the term. The course trains skills in critical reading of media, art and performance objects.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Literacy, according to the OED, describes the unreflected capacity of being able to read, but also denotes a particular condition with respect to knowledge, awareness and experience: the capacity to engage with that what is being read in a well-informed and critical way. Literacy often gets associated with words, with verbal language and books, but can also describe other reading skills, as, for example, in visual literacy. Corporeal literacy is a strategic term meant to make space for a further expansion of the notion of literacy to include our bodily engagement with what we find ourselves confronted with. In this course, we study texts by (among others) Mark Hansen, Lakof and Johnson, Shaun Gallagher, Vivian Sobchack , Laura Marks and Brian Rotman. Students are invited to explore the potential of these readings for the analysis of encounters with media of different kinds.

The course trains skills in critical reading and analysis of media, art and performance objects and allows students to develop rhetorical argumentation, which can be applied to a variety of professional fields (cultural institutions, academia, education, etc.)</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: masters selected topics in general relativity of relevance for cosmology, and knows the thermal history of the Universe and the importance of entropy conservation
has knowledge of the physics of the electroweak transition and possible scenarios
knows the QCD transition in the early Universe and is aware of modern view on nucleosynthesis
knows the physics of photon decoupling, understands the information stored in cosmic microwave background radiation and has knowledge of cosmological defects

can work with scalar field models of cosmic inflation: their advantages and drawbacks, and knows of the generation of cosmological perturbations during inflation and formation of cosmological structure
<style type=""text/css"">

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: "The course begins with an invitation to cosmology, including a review of the main cosmological probes, the current standard cosmological model and future theoretical and observational prospects. Then homogeneous and isotropic cosmologies (FLRW spaces) are discussed, as well as horizons and expansion. Primordial nucleosynthesis is reviewed and the leading candidates for baryogenesis. The course continues with a detailed derivation the formalism of cosmological perturbation theory during the various ages of the universe. Next a detailed treatment of the cosmic microwave background is presented, followed by large scale structures. The course then addresses the problem of the generation of primordial perturbations and the mechanism of inflation. Finally, the course ends with an overview of cosmological probes such as for example galaxies, cluster and gravitational lensing and present the main statistical tools for the data analysis."

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171932,2016,Course by an International Guest Lecturer,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['Docent(en) van de opleiding (GW)', 'M. Terrall']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175810,2016,Craft of research Workshop I: Contexts, roles and strategies",English,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, students have learned:

column2: • some common conceptual tools to connect research and practices in the realm of public administration and organizational science;
• to explore different positions with regard to connections between research and practices and the context in which these positions are developed;
• develop their own position with regard to connections between research and practices in the realm of public administration and organizational science.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Public administration theory and public administration practices are closely connected. Knowledge developed by scholars affects practices and provokes innovations in public administration practice. In turn these innovations guide research agendas and new questions for scholars. Knowledge and practices in these fields may be closely connected but both research and practice represent quite different fundamental logics.
This course aims to familiarize you with these different logics and the connections between them.

In this course you will examine the different contexts in which public administration and organizational researchers operate. You will explore the different functions research and other forms of knowledge in these contexts. You will learn what roles researchers and centres of expertise can choose to adopt in view of this. For three of the most important role clusters, you will be challenged to investigate what strategic, communicative and ethical considerations researchers have to engage with. You will learn about good and not so good practice, and will be working through key dilemmas that may arise in the zone where ‘knowledge’ meets ‘policy’.

Working with two instructors who have performed research and led research units in a wide variety of academic and applied settings, you will learn to appreciate the different scripts you are expected to follow in what is often referred to as ‘pure’ (or ‘academic’) as opposed to ‘applied’ research. Through examining cases and controversies as well as through site visits and guest lectures from specialists you will learn to distinguish between various forms of ‘applied’ research:

column2: • ‘public science’: seeking to influencing public debate and public policy as an academic researcher or as part of an independent think tank;
• ‘working on the inside’: working in a knowledge role within a government organization or government advisory body;
• ‘consultancy’: working for a commercial provider of social-scientific knowledge, expertise, advise and training

column1: For the major assignment, the group will split into three streams, each of which will conduct field research on one of these three types of knowledge-policy interfaces. The teams will present their findings in a symposium before a jury of experts.
In this course we use three different methods:

column2: • In a number of seminars the group explore the literature and the context of the debate in which these books figure. You will work on an individual paper in which you will develop your own position in this debate.

• During three site visits you will be connected with three different research contexts (Tranzo, an academic work shop that focuses on innovations in health care, the WRR, an advisory body firmly grounded in academia, and McKinsey, a consulting firm that developed and triggered innovations in both organization practice and organization theory).
• In a closing session you will prepare a pitch for one of the contexts we visit. A jury panel will reflect on the pitches.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176349,2016,Craft of research workshop II: Analysis and persuasion, general part",English,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['Externe docent'],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this fourth and final course of the programme, introducing research methods, the focus will be on the back end of the research process: making sense of the data gathered, crafting coherent and persuasive stories, and communicating those stories in an effective and responsible fashion. This part of the craft of research holds different (but comparable) challenges for researchers working mainly with numerical data and research working mainly with qualitative data.
In a series of four workshops, you will learn about aspects of research that you will all have to deal with: ethics, visualizing, writing and the academic review procedure.

Increasingly, researchers have to think through the ethical side of their work and defend it to an ethical committee. In this workshop, members of ethical committees come to share their experiences. Secondly, research can be visualized in many ways. You will get a short training in visualizing your work in a poster form. Researchers also engage in writing. This is a craft that they can learn by doing and by studying examples (successes and failures). Finally, research goes through review procedures, informal and formal ones. In this workshop, editors of scientific journals share their experiences about the review process.
After this general part, you choose one of the following modules to complete the course:

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176354,2016,Craft of research workshop II: Analysis and persuasion: From notes, texts, recordings and pictures to stories",English,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['Externe docent'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this module students are able to:

column2: • code and interpret a range of qualitative data;
• make a comparison across qualitative data sets;
• make various sorts of qualitative data displays;

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

When doing fieldwork, researchers can generate all sorts of qualitative data. There may be fieldnotes, interview recordings, pictures, policy documents and other materials to work with. There are various ways to analyze these rich data. Through an iterative process, procedural systematicity and an attitude of doubt, these all aim to build knowledge claims about the ways actors in the field make sense of their worlds. Importantly, building such knowledge claims itself is a kind of sense-making.

In this module you will learn about the principles of qualitative analysis and the ways in which qualitative analyses should be done. In addition, you will work with data throughout the module. We will be condensing, coding and comparing qualitative data. You will learn to do specific analyses, like narrative analysis. Furthermore, we will creatively display data in accessible form (table, figure, and more) and you will become more experienced in writing up a qualitative analysis and methods statements.
Finally, qualitative researchers have developed particular quality standards that help them to establish the quality of qualitative research.
The meetings of the module are interactive, allowing you to both get a better understanding of what is known about qualitative data analysis and to delve into issues you find important.

column2: • the theory of qualitative data analysis through texts on qualitative research methods,
• exemplary studies from the field of Public Administration and Organization Science that help to understand the quality of qualitative studies (what is convincing, what is trustworthy, etc.), and
• (practical) aspects of doing analysis through (in total) six assignments you make.

column1: During the meetings you are expected to work on your skills as a critical, analytic researcher. Consequently, you are expected to discover, fail, comment, reflect and repeat.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176351,2016,Craft of research workshop II: Analysis and persuasion: From numbers to stories,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['Externe docent'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this module, students are able to:

column2: • obtain approval for their research design from an ethical committee;
• conduct a thorough basic analysis in which hypotheses are tested and evaluated;
• visually present the results of their analysis in an academic poster.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

For those researchers whose basic data-collection product is numbers, the challenge in moving from data gathering to analysis and reporting is to give substantive meaning to those numbers. To get there, they have at their disposal a wide variety of statistical and/or mathematical techniques, which serve to produce interpretations as well as to test the validity and reliability of those interpretations. Once researchers have conducted the statistical analysis, they need to find appropriate ways of communicating the findings that emerge from the analysis to both specialized and lay audiences. The communication can involve visual representations of numbers in parsimonious and creative ways but also well-crafted stories that give meaning to the numbers that are at the heart of the analysis.

This module consists of 8 sessions where we delve into (1) the ethical aspects of our research; (2) go over the theoretical expectations and (3) carefully inspect the data we are going to use in our statistical and/or mathematical analysis; obtain elementary knowledge and comprehension of (4) regression analysis; (5) logistic regression analysis; and (6) multilevel analysis. We then (7) evaluate our hypotheses and (8) visualize the results of our analysis in a research poster.
We will ask you to prepare for class and participate actively.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179887,2016,Crash course introduction to rational homotopy theory,English,Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. I. Moerdijk'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Rational homotopy theory is the study of (simply connected) topological spaces up to ""rational equivalence"", where one identifies spaces if they are related by a map inducing isomorphisms in the homotopy groups after these groups have been tensored with the rationals. This results in a very beautiful theory, initially developed by Quillen and Sullivan, which can be described by purely algebraic objects of different kinds, for example by commutative differential graded algebras over the rationals.In the course, we will discuss some basic ingredients of this theory, for example, how to geometrically mimic ""tensoring with the rationals"", and how to associate to a topological space such a cdga by a construction somewhat reminiscent of the de Rham complex of a manifold.
Literature: we will produce notes as we go along
Prerequisites: basic knowledge of algebraic topology. We will freely base ourselves on some of the content of the (overlapping) course notes
Learning goals: active mastery of basic techniques of central importance in much of comtemporary pure maths
Examination: to be discussed, depending on the number of students.
Time and place: The course will run  for four weeks, from 21 February until 17 March

Rational homotopy theory is the study of (simply connected) topological spaces up to ""rational equivalence"", where one identifies spaces if they are related by a map inducing isomorphisms in the homotopy groups after these groups have been tensored with the rationals. This results in a very beautiful theory, initially developed by Quillen and Sullivan, which can be described by purely algebraic objects of different kinds, for example by commutative differential graded algebras over the rationals.In the course, we will discuss some basic ingredients of this theory, for example, how to geometrically mimic ""tensoring with the rationals"", and how to associate to a topological space such a cdga by a construction somewhat reminiscent of the de Rham complex of a manifold.
