column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The theme of this two-part course is the dynamics of law in a European and international context, the central issue being the legal intertwining of the national, European and international legal orders. In this second part of the course, the focus is on course work, or research, that you will have to do on the implications of Europeanization (and internationalization) on private law and criminal law respectively. The method is a combination of teaching and presentation and writing of research papers. Both fields of law are studied through the lens of the interaction and intertwining with EU law . The private and criminal law dimension are dealt with in a consecutive way.
Place of this course within the curriculum:

column2: • Compulsory course in the master Legal Research

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172886,2016,Dynamics of sedimentary systems,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. J.T. Eggenhuisen'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In this course, students are invited to explore the mechanisms that govern the distribution, architecture, and characteristics of deposits preserved in the geological record at the level of a Master in Science.

Throughout the thematic treatment described below, students will be confronted with the mechanisms “at work” in modelling exercises both in the silicon environment of numerical modelling as well as the gritty environment of the flume laboratory. These practical exercises will allow the students to strengthen their skills in modeling approaches and data treatment.

An optional three-day fieldtrip to Holocene and Jurassic tidal, coastal and shallow marine deposits will allow the students to use elementary observations on sedimentary facies to build models and interpretations of the evolution of past sedimentary systems.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Early in the course, emphasis is put on the effect the choice of temporal and spatial scales defined by a research question has on our approach to sediment transport dynamics. Following this, the hierarchy and scaling of the architecture of sedimentary successions is investigated. The structure of this architecture will be built on concepts of sequence stratigraphy. Once a clear perspective on the organization of deposits in parasequences, sequences, and shelf-clinoforms has been presented to the student, attention will shift to forcing mechanisms of deposit characteristics within subsets of deposits and depositional environments: Alluvial systems; transgressive systems and highstand deltas; tidal systems; and deep marine depositional systems. The course will conclude by challenging the students to investigate the validity and application of two oft (miss-)used concepts of Earth Sciences: “Walther’s Law”; and “The present is the key to the past”.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172813,2016,Dynamics of the earth's mantle,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['prof. dr. W. Spakman'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: To obtain a coherent physical understanding of the internal dynamics of the Earth and mantle convection and to be confronted with modern views on mantle dynamics and how it affects/drives surface deformation.
Specific Thorough understanding of concepts and theory regarding the dynamics of the Earth's mantle.

Create a proper entry level of knowledge such that students can study scientific papers on mantle dynamics, find their way into the complexity of mantle dynamics, being able to understand and evaluate scientific results.
Create basic understanding on the importance of mantle processes for driving surface change.
Improve presentation skills and preparation of a scientific presentation.
First experience with numerical modeling of mantle dynamics.

column4: By the end of the course, the student will

column5: have acquired fundamental theoretical knowledge, derived from first principles, of the equations describe continuummechanics;
have physical understanding of the internal dynamics of the Earth and mantle convection;
have obtained computer-aided experience creating basic flow patterns of mantle convection;
be confronted by literature study and presentations with modern views on mantle dynamics and how it affects / drives the near-surface deformation.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Mantle processes (e.g. deep mantle flow, plate tectonics & subduction ) drive surface change not only on geological time scales (oceanic basins and continental platforms, sedimentary basin formation, mountain building, plate boundary deformation, genesis of natural resources, ….) but also on the human time scale (natural disasters as earthquakes & volcanoes, sea level change, stability/mobility of the crust, …). In this course, the focus is on how we can study mantle dynamics from a mathematical-physical point of view. This will give students the proper entry to scientific papers on the subject and constitutes the proper basis for follow up courses in computational geophysics and guided research or master research in mantle dynamics. The lectures are accompanied by an exercise class and a computer practical.

Part 1: The course starts with a qualitative summary of current views on mantle convection in the Earth, which includes inferences on the style of mantle flow as "observed" with seismic tomography. The course continues with a brief review of continuum mechanics and rheology followed by a mathematical-physical treatment leading to the basic equations describing the dynamics of the crust-mantle system. This also encompasses a derivation of the energy (heat, Temperature) equation from first principles. Next the steps are made toward real-Earth application encompassing basic approximations, and scaling of differential equations leading to non-dimensional quantities with important coefficients, such as the Rayleigh number that characterize the style of flow and dynamics. The last subject is a treatment of linear stability analysis leading to a solution of the onset-of-convection problem. This more theoretical part is supported by extensive handout includes many exercises.

Part 2: The second part of the course concerns the practical scientific implementation of the basic theory for studies of crust-mantle dynamics. This comprises the step from mantle dynamics theory to numerical modelling and particular topics of application and discussion of scientific papers from the recent literature. This part ends  with the presentation by students on various topics of choice, e.g. generation of mantle plumes, thermo-chemical convection, plates, subduction & convection, interaction between mantle flow and slab subduction, surface evolution and mantle dynamics, dynamics topography, ..., all based on recent literature. This final seminar will be cast as a typical conference session.
Part 3: In parallel with Part 2, students are actively getting experience in a computerlab dealing with e.g. the basics of thermal convection and solid-state phase transitions in mantle.
The final mark results from a normal weighed average of the results of 3 parts with the following weights:

column5: Part 1:  50% of the final mark.
Part 2:  30% of the final mark.
Part 3:  20% of the final mark.

column4: For each part at least a 5.0 must be scored but the final mark must be a 6.0 or higher to pass the course.

In part 1 the students will be primarily tested on their mathematical-physical understanding of the quantitative formulation underlying mantle convection. Particularly, in parts 2 and 3 the students will be tested and graded on their ability in critical and analytical reasoning, on creativity in building sensible connections between the topics treated and other topics in mantle dynamics and the broader earth sciences. The exercise and computerlab also assesses students creativity in constructing solution strategies, in solving problems and on providing proper argumentation for solutions found.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172102,2016,Dynamics of the Cultural Field,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. A.C.N. van Beusekom', 'dr. P. Lelieveldt']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Aan het eind van deze cursus heeft de student:
·         Basale kennis verworden over theorievorming rondom cultuurbeleid en de relatie tussen media, cultuur en samenleving
·         Inzicht gekregen in het Nederlandse culturele veld en in de interne structuur en de dynamiek van enkele aansprekende instellingen daarbinnen;
·         Inzicht gekregen in de wisselwerking tussen het culturele veld met de rest van de samenleving en het onderzoek dat daarnaar wordt verricht.
Tevens heb je academische vaardigheden verworven:
·         in het opzoeken en analyseren van informatie;
·         in het doordenken van de praktische gevolgen van theoretische analyses;
·         in het uitvoeren van een klein empirisch onderzoek naar een instelling in de culturele sector;
·         in mondeling en schriftelijk presenteren van onderzoeksgegevens.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus staan niet de media- of cultuuruitingen zelf (theatervoorstellingen, films, televisieprogramma’s e.d.) centraal, maar richten we ons op het culturele veld: de context waarbinnen deze uitingen worden geproduceerd, gedistribueerd en vertoond. Media- en cultuuruitingen worden beschouwd als het resultaat van (samenwerkings)processen, en niet als op zichzelf staande fenomenen of het werk van één duidelijke maker. Deze samenwerking kan tijdelijk of éénmalig zijn, maar ook duurzaam. In het laatste geval kan dit leiden tot de vorming van organisaties die de productie, de distributie en de receptie van kunstwerken sturen aan de hand van gedeelde waarden en vaststaande regels. Dit fenomeen wordt ook wel aangeduid als de institutionalisering van media en cultuur.

In de cursus wordt de bik zowel naar binnen als naar buiten gericht. De blik naar binnen richt zich op de vraag wat voor soorten culturele instellingen er zijn en welke relaties er tussen deze instellingen bestaan. De blik naar buiten richt zich op de plaats van media en cultuur in de samenleving, onder andere door te kijken naar het debat over de waarde van kunst en cultuur, de grondslagen van het media- en cultuurbeleid en de motieven van mensen om naar media en cultuur te (komen) kijken. Naast dit meer op de praktijk georiënteerde perspectief biedt de cursus een introductie in de gangbare theoretische benaderingen van het fenomeen. We kijken naar opvattingen over (de totstandkoming van) media en cultuur binnen onder meer de kunstsociologie, de kunstfilosofie en de kunsteconomie. Zo is er aandacht voor concepten als conventies, hoge en lage cultuur, prestige, instituties en creatieve industrie. Deze concepten worden besproken aan de hand van het handboek Sociology of the Arts van Victoria Alexander, een reader met wetenschappelijke teksten en beleidsteksten, en concrete cases (onder meer ingebracht door gastsprekers). Op deze manier wordt een beeld geschetst van het wetenschappelijke discours over de media- en cultuurwereld, en van het debat erover binnen de samenleving en de media- en cultuurwereld zelf. Als eindopdracht wordt met behulp van de aangereikte concepten een veldonderzoek uitgevoerd naar een culturele instelling. Daarmee wordt geleerd om de relatie tussen theorie en praktijk te leggen, en bovendien de mogelijkheid geboden om contact te leggen met de media- en cultuurpraktijk. In dit opzicht draagt dit onderdeel van de cursus ook bij aan de beroepsoriëntatie van de student.

Deze cursus is een academische contextcursus, wat inhoudt dat de cursus een oriëntatie biedt op een specifieke benadering binnen het domein van media en cultuur. De cursus biedt daarbij onder andere een inleiding op het minorprogramma Kunst, Beleid en Maatschappij, en sluit goed aan bij de thematiek van de masteropleiding Arts and Society.

Students who are required to return to their home university by the end of December, are allowed to choose an early exit option. Students must always make individual arrangements with the course coordinator. In general, there are two options that can be facilitated:
1. Finishing the course before Christmas break, receiving 5 ECTS for the course.
2. Completing the course by 'distance learning' (extra assignments, papers etc) in the month of January, receiving 7.5 ECTS for the course.

In this course we will focus on the relationships between organizations. Cooperation between organizations has become a strategic activity and takes many forms. Firms intensify their outsourcing activities, integrate supply chains, invest in customer and supplier relationship management, form strategic alliances and partnerships, etcetera. How can IT help organizations to achieve win-win relationships with their environment, considering the increase in interdependencies and interorganizational coordination problems? In this course this challenge is addressed from both a managerial and technological perspective. In practice, students will jointly perform a scientific research project to apply different theoretical and empirical approaches to the subject.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: E-Business staat voor het managen van een bedrijf door optimaal gebruik te maken van de mogelijkheden van Internet. ICT en Internet maken het mogelijk om bedrijven op een andere manier te organiseren, maar hiervoor is ook een plan en een visie nodig. In dit vak behandelen we de technieken, modellen en applicaties voor E-business en E-commerce.
Onderwerpen die de revue zullen passeren zijn:

column5: Wat zijn E-business en E-commerce? Wat zijn de overeenkomsten, verschillen en de relatie tussen deze twee begrippen?
Wat zijn de strategieen en business modellen achter E-business?
Welke hardware-, software- en telecom-ontwikkelingen zijn belangrijk voor E-business?
Enkele belangrijke applicaties van E-business: Supply Chain Management, E-procurement, Customer Relationship Management.
Welke veranderingen zijn nodig in een organisatie of bedrijf om de overstap naar E-business te maken?

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170917,2016,EDSCI01 Theories in learning,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. S.F. Akkerman', 'L.H. Bronkhorst']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of the course with a successful grade, you can     demonstrate,     both     orally     and     in     writing:
• mastery of basic concepts for describing and comparing learning theories;
• ability to determine the historical roots and the contemporary value of a learning theory;
• ability to draw implications of learning theories for analysing and designing educational situations;
• ability to identify and describe the learning theories advanced by a single educational scholar given his or her scholarly work.

Many theories of learning exist at different levels of explanation. One can find grand theories making paradigmatic claims about learning as representing the course of social life, theoretical approaches making claims on how to understand learning best, and theoretical models making empirical claims on how learning occurs or is best facilitated. Learning theories moreover, are not static as contemporary theories extend and update traditional ones. This course – Theories in Learning – discusses various (smaller and more comprehensive) theories of learning, placing them in their historical contexts, in relation to each other, as well as in the context of current society and educational practice. There will be discussion about the similarities and differences between various theories, making course participants aware of different understandings and discourses that are reflected in educational literature. The course will work towards an elaborate framework by means of which learning theories can be described, compared and debated on a more abstract level,. Your understanding of this framework is put to the test in a final analysis of a scholar’s work.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170870,2016,EDSCI02 Introduction to educational neuroscience,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. P.P.M. Leseman'],,Course goals

The course aims to introduce students to the emerging field of educational neuroscience, its main research methods, its findings, and its implications. Starting with a brief introduction into the biology of the brain, from cells to structural brain anatomy, and from computational processes on the neuron level to the operation of higher brain functions, such as attention, working memory, and executive control, the course will focus specifically on neuro-constructivist approaches to brain-development and highlight experience-expectant and experience-dependent mechanisms. The basic neuro-cognitive and neuro-affective insights are applied to learning language, literacy, and math in the real contexts of the family and the classroom, addressing also the affective and social processes involved. An important aim of the course is to make student familiar with neuroscience research methods and experimental research designs. About half of the course, therefore, will be spent on a hands-on work assignment in the form of an experiment in educational neuroscience in the lab using eye-tracking and electrophysiological brain measures (EEG).

The course is also part of the clinical qualification track in the EDSCI programme. Students with an appropriate Bachelor or Premaster specialization Special Education (Studiepad / Premaster Orthopedagogiek) who choose for this track will do their work assignment in the Ambulatorium under supervision of a licensed clinical teacher, using eye-tracking and/or electrophysiological brain measures as additional diagnostic tools. The assignment  will result in a report of the diagnostic examination and evaluation of a student with learning and school-behavioral problems (required diagnostic case study 1).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This Course will teach students to use multivariate statistics for the analysis of empirical data. At the end of the course students should be able to determine which statistical model should be used to investigate different types of research questions, e.g. regression, ANOVA, repeated measures and logistic regression analysis. Furthermore, the students should be able to execute the corresponding analyses using SPSS and interpret the results. Students have encountered most of these models in the bachelor programmes, but still have to develop confidence in applying these models and procedures while analysing empirical data. Special attention will be given to the practical issues: checking the model assumptions and dealing with violations. New topics are power, contrast testing, bootstrapping, s, missing data and imputation techniques, and a further advanced topic in multivariate statistics.

There are options to follow this course as a non-Research Master student (eg Elective student, PhD student etc). Please contact the teacher about these options on time, ie before July 15 (for courses in semester 1) / December 15 (for courses in semester 2). You will need written approval from the teacher (an email is sufficient) in order to register for this course at the Faculty’s Student Information Point (Faculty Students Desks). Note that for external parties, costs for participation may be involved.
Relation between tests and goals of course
1.      Refreshing previously mastered knowledge of multivariate analyses.

2.      Enhancing knowledge about multivariate analyses by studying and/or practicing topics not encountered in previous education (e.g. repeated measure analysis and logistic regression), and/or by studying related topics (e.g., contrast testing and multiple testing issues).
3.      Apply knowledge of General Linear Model to design an appropriate statistical model for a given research question and dataset.
4.      Being able to perform the analyses mentioned in the previous three points using SPSS and being able to interpret the results.
5.      Knowing which statistical model should be used to investigate different types of research questions.
6.      Acquire knowledge on new developments in statistics (e.g. Bootstrapping and the changing ideas on hypothesis testing).
7.      Reporting skills in writing about design choice and choice for statistical test.
Presentation skills in criticizing existing article on logistic regression analysis.
Assignment 1:       Short review and presentation, 20% of final grade.
Assignment 2:       Data-analysis plan, 20% of final grade.
Assignment 3:       Analysis and essay  on an advanced topic in multivariate statistics, 20% of final grade.
Assignment 4:       Presentation concerning logistic regression analysis, 20% of final grade.
Assignment 5:       Reading questions handed in each week. One randomly chosen set of questions will be graded, 20% of final grade.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170895,2016,EDSCI04 Integrative practical I,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. E. van de Weijer-Bergsma', 'prof. dr. P.P.M. Leseman']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In this integrative practical, theoretical and methodological knowledge obtained in the other EdSci courses will be integrated. This integrative practical takes place during the first semester of the first year, parallel to the other Edsci courses. In this practical students complete three assignments of which two are graded. Students are provided with parts of a research article and they have to write a missing part of that article. In the first assignment students get the first part of an article up to the interpretation of the data analysis and they have to write the last part of the article (interpretation of the data analysis and discussion). In the second assignment they get the first part of another article including the research questions and the method section but without the results and they have to do the data analysis, interpret the outcomes and formulate conclusions. Last, students develop a research proposal (problem, theoretical background, method) of their own, as a first preparation for the choice of a theme for their master thesis. In the meetings students are actively involved in discussing their assignments with their fellow students and giving them peer-feedback as well as in discussing recent relevant developments in the field.
Upon completion of the course the student is able to:
a) demonstrate, orally and in writing, the competence to integrate theoretical, methodological and statistical arguments, decisions and interpretations;

b) demonstrate, orally and in writing, the competence to define a meaningful research problem, make decisions about data gathering and data analysis, carry out the data analysis, interpret the outcomes, evaluate the research, and formulate conclusions;
c) make and motivate a provisional choice of a theme for the master thesis.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170871,2016,EDSCI05 Theories on teaching and teachers,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['B.L. Kennedy, PhD', 'L.H. Bronkhorst', 'prof. dr. J.W.F. van Tartwijk']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The history of research on teaching and teachers has moved from the analysis of student outcomes in relation to teacher attitudes, via teaching behaviours and teaching styles to teacher cognition, and, recently to teaching and student outcomes again. In this course this evolution of research will be studied and critically examined. An overview will be discussed of theoretical approaches from very naive (e.g. teacher attitudes contribute directly and indirectly to student learning) to rather complex (e.g. student perceptions of teacher behaviour in classrooms in interaction with student characteristics, class and teacher characteristics, determine student learning). Through readings, discussion, and assignments students will gain a more complete understanding of the complexity of teaching and teacher functioning, and how educational researchers go about conducting research on teaching and teachers today. Students will learn about diverse theoretical approaches to teacher effectiveness and critically examine strengths and weaknesses of these approaches.
Theories and research on teaching and teachers will be discussed from different perspectives such as:

·         The interpersonal perspective studies teaching in terms of real-time teacher student interactions and the development of teacher student relationships, which can be studies using perception data. A (dynamic) systems theoretical perspective is used.
·         The learning activities perspective studies teaching focussing on teachers’ roles in facilitating students’ knowledge (re)construction by means of students’ learning activities.
·         The content and pedagogical content perspectives study teaching from the viewpoint of why specific subject matter is taught, and how it is taught best.
·         The moral perspective focuses on how teachers deal with values and moral issues that also are a part of the teacher role.
·         The innovative perspective studies and critically assesses innovations in education and what they entail for teaching and learning.
·         The assessment perspective explores the impact of assessment on teaching and learning.
·         The teacher education and professional development perspective studies how teachers are (continuously) prepared for teaching.
·         The teachers as objects of study perspective, exploring teachers in relative isolation, often focussing on teacher expertise and/or teacher identity.
Every theme will be discussed in terms of: (1) the theory of teaching itself; (2) research on teaching within that theoretical approach.

In the course, special attention will be paid to observation as a strategy for data gathering because observation is an important means of data gathering in research in education, specifically research on teaching, and because observation is not dealt with in other EdSci courses.</body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170802,2016,EDSCI06 Individual differences in learning and special needs education,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. E.H. Kroesbergen', 'dr. W.B.T. Blom', 'prof. dr. M.J. Jongmans']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After the course, students are expected to have knowledge of specific learning disabilities and giftedness, and to be able to critically review the research literature, to critically evaluate diagnostic processes, and to design research projects in the field of special educational needs. Students following the clinical track are also expected to be able to report on a diagnostic process of an individual child with special educational needs.
The main learning objectives of this course are:
1.      Identify the main sources of individual differences in learning academic skills
2.      Critically reflect on commonly used designs and methods in research on individual differences in learning and children with special educational needs
3.      Critically reflect on commonly used classification systems and diagnostic or inclusion/exclusion criteria (practice and/or research)
4.      Formulate solutions for the educational challenges presented by individual differences in learning
5.      Critically reflect on different educational policies towards individual differences in learning and special educational needs
6.      Develop an argument for your position in a current theoretical debate related to individual differences in learning based on scientific research

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Large individual differences exist between children in their development of academic skills such as reading, writing or mathematics. Some children encounter severe difficulties in learning one or more of these skills while they develop ‘normally’ in other respects. These children are called students with specific learning disabilities. Estimations differ, but it is generally agreed that approximately 5% to 10% of all school-aged children in the Western world show severe and persistent problems in acquiring academic skills. At the other end of the spectrum are children with special gifts and talents in one or more (academic) areas. And, of course, a large group of children fall into a mid-category, but they still may have special educational needs, for example related to problems with attention, working memory or emotional problems. Children may also show large intra-individual differences; they may be good at language but not so good at mathematics. In general, schools in the Netherlands are not well equipped to meet the educational needs of all children. Both teacher education and educational research often focus on the average child, which doesn’t acknowledge these large inter- and intra-individual differences in children. The aim of this course is to provide students with an overview of the main causes of individual differences in learning, including specific learning disabilities, giftedness, and bilingualism, as well as their implications for education and educational research.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170933,2016,EDSCI07 Introduction in multilevel and structural equation modelling,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. L.D.N.V. Wijngaards', 'prof. dr. E.L. Hamaker']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: In this course  there are two tests and two assignments (consisting of multiple exercises spread over multiple weeks):
a) Students develop knowledge and understanding of multilevel modeling (Knowledge and understanding)
b) Students develop knowledge and understanding of the computer program HLM (Knowledge and understanding)
c) Students learn to translate research questions into (aspects of) multilevel models, and specify relevant multilevel models in SPSS and HLM (Knowledge and understanding)
d) Students can translate research questions into sequence of models to be run (Learning skills)
e) Students can use specialized software (Learning skills)
f) Students can interpret SPSS/HLM output in terms of relevance and statistical significance (Applying knowledge and understanding)
g) Students can relate SPSS/HLM output to research question (Applying knowledge and understanding)
a) Students develop knowledge and understanding of multilevel modeling (Knowledge and  understanding)
b) Students develop knowledge and understanding of the computer program HLM (Knowledge and understanding)
c) Students learn to translate research questions into (aspects of) multilevel models, and specify relevant multilevel models in SPSS and HLM (Knowledge and understanding)
d) Students can translate research questions into sequence of models to be run (Learning skills)

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Two techniques that are often encountered are multilevel modeling (MLM) and structural equation modeling (SEM). MLM is appropriate for handling nested data, for instance, patients in hospitals, or occasions in people. MLM can be used to study the within cluster and the between cluster relationships between an outcome variable and predictors. In the lab meetings SPSS and HLM are used. SEM covers both factor analyses and path analyses. It can be used to investigate the underlying factor structure and compare this across groups (i.e., measurement invariance), more complex mediation models, longitudinal data, and to compare distinct theories. In the lab meetings Mplus is used.

There are options to follow this course as a non-EdSCi student (eg Elective student, PhD student etc). Please contact the teacher about these options on time, ie before July 15 (for courses in semester 1) / December 15 (for courses in semester 2). You will need written approval from the teacher (an email is sufficient) in order to register for this course at the Faculty’s Student Information Point (Faculty Student Desk). Note that for external parties, costs for participation may be involved.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170993,2016,EDSCI08  Integrative practical II,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['drs. M.T. Mainhard'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Upon completion of the course the student is able to:
a) demonstrate, orally and in writing, the competence to integrate theoretical and methodological -statistical arguments, decisions and interpretations on an advanced level;
b) critically and imaginatively discuss ideas and possibilities for integrating different theoretical strands;
c) formulate meaningful and innovative research questions and hypotheses.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This integrative practical is scheduled in the second semester of the first year, parallel to other EDSCI courses. In this practical, students complete three assignments. The first assignment concerns the application of multilevel modeling and the second assignment of structural equation modeling to data of researchers that participate in the EDSCI master. Students are provided with original data and research questions, they specify multilevel and SEM models, run the analyses, report the results, and formulate conclusions. In the third assignment students prepare a NWO-format research proposal, preferably related to the subject of their master’s thesis. Students also prepare a (NWO-format) review a for a fellow student’s research proposal. Assignments integrate theoretical Edsci courses (01, 02, 05, 06) and the course on multilevel modeling and structural equation modeling (EdSci07). During the meetings, students are supposed to get actively involved in discussing their assignments with the other students and to provide feedback on their fellow students’ work.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170979,2016,EDSCI09 Interaction in learning environments,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. J.E. van de Pol', 'prof. dr. L. Kester']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course focuses on constructivist, situated, cognitive and     socio-cultural     approaches     to     learning.     These     approaches     emphasize     the     importance     of     interaction     processes     in     learning     and     the     role     of     artifacts     or     tools     in     the     authentic     learning     environment.     Theoretically,     several     mechanisms     have     been     proposed     to     explain     the     learning     effects     of     interaction     processes     in     social     or     collaborative     learning     situations,     such     as     externalizing     knowledge,     active     engagement,     self-explanation,transactive     memory     and     distribution     of     cognitive     load,     negotiation,     co-construction     of     knowledge,     grounding,     coordination     processes,     maintaining     a     joint     problem     space,     (socio-)cognitive     conflict,     reflection,     and     reconstructing     knowledge     through     critical     argumentation.     Research     in     this     field     focuses     on     the     way     these     mechanisms     facilitate     learning     processes     and     on     the     way     these     interactive     learning     activities     can     be     supported     by     tools     or     arrangements     in     the     learning     situation.     The     effects     of     these     processes     will     be     analyzed     and     evaluated.     Upon     completion     of     the     course     the     student     is     able     to:
- demonstrate, orally and in writing, the mastery of the basic concepts;
- apply theoretical concepts to evaluation of research literature;
- apply theoretical concepts to design of learning situations;
- analyze learning interaction from different perspectives.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171081,2016,EDSCI10 EducationElective course I – clinical or research specialization,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. E.H. Kroesbergen', 'drs. M.T. Mainhard']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Specific academic objectives of this course are: a) learning to work with fellow scholars and/or in multidisciplinary teams b) learning to share knowledge and experiences within a team of educational researchers and professionals c) learning to apply relevant shared knowledge and experiences while collaborating on (clinical-diagnostic) research projects d) learning to debate with professionals and fellow educational researchers on theory and research (in English) e) learning to present (clinical) research findings and insights to audiences of specialists in English, both in written and verbal form f) learning to critically assess own views in light of the latest developments in the field.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course offers students four general options to choose from:

column5: Internship within one of the EdSci research groups or a national or international institute linked to the Utrecht research groups (e.g., the GSE programme of Rutgers University (USA) or Curtin University (Australia)), or an internship in more policy (e.g., Ministry of Education, Educational Inspectorat) or practice (e.g., Dutch Council secondary education, consultancy firms) oriented organisations. In combination with EdSci 11 (Elective II) a substantial international traineeship, also abroad, is feasible. In the traineeship students participate in ongoing research and/or connect their thesis research with the theoretical and methodological aspects of a research group. The goal of the internship is to get familiar with doing research within a university or more policy/practice oriented setting and getting acquainted with the various steps in doing research. During the internship, students learn how a research group functions, learn to collaborate in a research or multidisciplinary team and cooperate with colleagues, critically reflect on own functioning as researcher within a team, reporting clearly, completely, and concisely, collecting and processing data (data entry, scale construction, development of code book), presenting (orally and written), learn how research connects to educational policy and practice.

Together with EdSci11 (Elective II) this course ispart of the clinical qualification track in the EDSCI programme. Students with an appropriate Bachelor or Premaster specialization Special Education (Studiepad / Premaster Orthopedagogiek) who choose for this track will do an internship in  the Ambulatorium under supervision of a licensed clinical teacher. During the clinical internship students will do the third required diagnostic case study and further elaborate the first and second diagnostic case studies (respectively EDSCI02, EDSCI06). Other professional skills concern communication with important stakeholders, such as parents and school teachers.

Together with EdSci11 (Elective II) this course part of the combined qualification track EDSCI and Youth Policy and Society (MOV) programme or EDSCI and the academic master Educational Sciences (Onderwijswetenschappen). Students who choose for this track will do a course, an internship or research traineeship under supervision of a teacher with expertise in either national or international societal education issues or educational sciences. Professional skills concern communication with important stakeholders, such as parents, school teachers and policymakers.
A course from one of the other research master programs.

column3: This course is closely related to EDSCI11 Educational Elective II.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170804,2016,EDSCI12A Research seminar educational sciences I,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. S.F. Akkerman', 'R.C . Zwart']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Research Seminar aims to stimulate the development of a researcher’s mind, which includes knowledge of doing research (e.g., about different research phases), research skills (e.g., systematic way working), as well as an academic attitude (e.g., curiosity, open mindedness, self-critical). In addition, specific skills aimed at in this course are:

·               Detecting,       discussing       and       solving       problems       encountered       during       the       preparation,       data       gathering,       analysis,       and       reporting       stage       of       a       research       project
·               Listening       and       giving       feedback       to       others
·               Following       formal       academic       guidelines,       including       research       ethics       and       APA       style       (6<sup>th</sup>       edition)

The Research Seminar (7.5 ECTS) takes place during the second year of the Research Master programme. It runs parallel to the Research Master Thesis (Edsci13) and is set up to help the student – through readings, discussions and debate – develop those academic skills and solve actual research problems encountered while doing the Master’s Thesis research.

The course will follow a flexible schedule of of meeting every three weeks. In a meeting, the course coordinator or a guest speaker presents a subject, show pointers to resources and sets assignments. In addition, time in the meetings will be used to let the students present and discuss their problems and progress in the research. In this way the Edsci students form a small research group under the supervision of the coordinator of the Research Seminar, to support each other in their research tasks.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171147,2016,EDSCI13 Master's thesis EDSM,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. P.P.M. Leseman'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The master thesis is embedded in previous research and literature on the chosen topic and includes a theoretical elaboration of the research problem, followed by an empirical test of some implications of the theory and a discussion of results and conclusions. The thesis has the form of a publishable research paper and thus includes: (1) an introduction in which a theoretical framework is formulated and relevant empirical research is integrated, concluded by a set of hypotheses; (2) a method section with a description of the sample, procedure, design, analyses, and measurement instruments; (3) a results section in which the data are analysed and the hypotheses are tested; (4) a discussion that summarises the main conclusions and describes their theoretical and practical implications. In addition to the thesis, students can prepare a research proposal based on the topic of their thesis for a subsequent PhD study (though this is not required). The topic of the thesis should preferably be integrated in the ongoing research programmes of EdSci research groups. The decision on the topic for a thesis is taken at the end of the first year in the programme. The preparation of the thesis and the research proposal starts in the second semester of the first year in cooperation with the Integrative Practical (EdSci08) and the problem formulation, relevant theories and hypotheses are discussed with fellow students and lecturer(s). This is followed by the Research seminar (EdSci12), in which methods, analyses, results, and interpretation are likewise discussed.
- The ability to write a research paper / research article</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The EMOS course module takes place in the first and second semester of the second year. It runs along Preparation for the Thesis (MSBBSS10), Research seminar 1/2 (EMOS) and Thesis (MSBBSS13). The course has seven parts. The first part is approximately 1 ECTS, each of the other parts approximately 2 ECTS:

1. Aspects of official statistics. The aim of the course is to give insight into the relevance of official statistics for society, to give an overview of the most important international organisations and their respective roles, the European Statistical System and their legal basis and confidentiality laws, to understand the different kind of data sources (sample surveys (cross sectional, longitudinal), administrative data, big data, integrated data sources), to understand the European Statistics Code of practice and how it applies to the different steps of data.

2. Sampling and estimation. The aim is to give insight into the design of surveys and into statistical inference based on survey data, considering population and sampling frames, sampling designs, designs of survey experiments, adaptive survey design, sampling and non-observation error, nonresponse reduction and adjustment methods and small area estimation.
3. Statistical data editing. The aim is to give insight into typical data editing and item non-response problems in official statistics and methods for dealing with them.
4. Administrative and big data. The aim is to give insight into the possibilities and typical quality problems of administrative and Big Data sources and methods for dealing with them.

5. Data management in statistical production. The aim of the course is to give an overview  of representation and processing of statistical data both on a technical and on a logical level, including the relation with enterprise architecture concepts, the production models usual in official statistics (e.g. metadata management, GSBPM) and monitoring and evaluating data quality.

6. Interpretation and presentation of official statistics. The aim is to understand methodological issues and to interpret correctly the outcomes in some important fields of official statistics (National Accounts, Input-output tables, Price statistics, Beyond GDP, poverty and inequality, unemployment, migration) and to give knowledge and tools for an effective way of presentation of data in tables, charts and advanced visual graphics.
7. Statistical disclosure control. The aim is to give insight into the relevance and techniques to prevent the disclosure of sensitive information in tables and micro data.

There are options to follow this course as a non-MSBBSS student (eg Elective student, PhD student etc). Please contact the teacher about these options on time, ie before July 15 (for courses in semester 1) / December 15 (for courses in semester 2). You will need written approval from the teacher (an email is sufficient) in order to register for this course at the Faculty’s Student Desk . Note that for external parties, costs for participation may be involved.

b. Using LaTex to create presentations. (Applying)

d. Communicate research findings by means of presentations. (Communication)

• Structuring, writing, and presentation of the master thesis (50%)
o Students are able to structure the report of their master thesis (Communication)

Research Seminar 1-2  takes place in the first and second semester of the second year. It runs along Preparation for the Thesis (MSBBSS10, the EMOS Core Module) and Thesis (MSBBSS13). In this research seminar students will:
1) Be taught to produce papers and slides with LaTeX. These tools will be used to write the thesis, which takes the form of a scientific paper and to communicate progress by means of presentations.
2) Be taught to clearly communicate and discuss research findings verbally and on paper.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192813,2016,Early Modern History,English,University College Roosevelt,,[],,
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174717,2016,Early Modern History: 1450 - 1850,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. J.J.M. Vandommele', 'dr. J.L. Salman']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: describe the most important developments in early modern Europe,
demonstrate a critical and well-informed perspective towards older notions of periodization, with their concomitant clichés about mentality, social structure, and progress,
assess the scholarly debate that first formed, and then demolished the notions mentioned above,
examine contemporary society from a more distant perspective, seeing its implicit prejudices and rules through the mirror of another age,
recognize various writings and artifacts as belonging to a particular period,
judge texts with a critical attitude through sharpened attention for styles of argumentation and defective reasoning,
evaluate historical sources on a basic level,
process knowledge for written and oral presentation.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course gives a chronological overview of European history in the early modern period, while also covering the borderlines with medieval, modern, and world history. Our perspective will include economic, political, and cultural aspects of different periods in the early modern age. The course develops a critical perspective towards widely disseminated notions about modernization, that described medieval and early modern society only as ‘stages’ in the development to modernity. Therefore, the course focuses on periods of a shorter time span within the early modern period, uncovering their idiosyncrasies as well as the interaction between different spheres: economy, political structures, mentality, etc. Generally speaking, specific themes are selected to enable the students to develop insight into the characteristics of these periods. From this starting point, finally, the subject of long term developments and trends are addressed. The subtle balance between the need to see similarities, structures and developments, and the necessity to discover ‘the past as another country’ forms the nexus of the course.

The course begins with a short introductory lecture highlighting central themes, ideally using visual material, music, etc. Having already studied the texts, students can now use these lectures to ask any questions they may have. The core element follows in the longer sessions where students have the main responsibility. They give short oral presentations and chair the resulting discussions. Historical sources are used for classroom close-reading and students exchange their interpretations of the texts; questions from the course manual can also be debated. Of course, the teacher participates and guides the discussion, but an ideal session should at least contain sections that are largely filled by student initiative.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172074,2016,Early Music History,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. R.C.I. Marinescu'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The course teaches students to identify, read, and digest advanced literature about pre-modern music, and trains students in research techniques and methodologies appropriate to pre-modern source materials and musical forms of expression. Course materials  typically are of an interdisciplinary nature and therefore will also open students’ eyes to the potential and relevance of interdisciplinary methodologies for musicological research.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Early Music History is part of the sequence 'Historical Musicology' (""verdiepingspakket Historische muziekwetenschap""). The course aims to familiarize students with salient aspects of sonic and music culture in medieval and early modern Europe and early modern colonial empires up to ca. 1800. For this purpose, the course first introduces (a selection of) pre-modern ways of conceptualizing music (e.g., the use of hexachords and the Guidonian hand), corresponding notations, and relevant source types. This is followed by practical applications of these concepts through the examination of one or several selected segments of repertoire in relevant cultural contexts. The typically high level of cultural alterity and interdisciplinarity of the course materials will help expand students' ways how to conceptualize music and musicking in an 'exotic' setting, while also opening their eyes for the necessity and fascination of interdisciplinary and contextual research in so-called 'data-poor' areas of inquiry. Besides students of musicology, this course is also of interest for students who have taken the minors Medieval Studies or Early Modern Studies in combination with a minor in Musicology.

Students who are required to return to their home university by the end of December, are allowed to choose an early exit option. Students must always make individual arrangements with the course coordinator. In general, there are two options that can be facilitated:
1. Finishing the course before Christmas break, receiving 5 ECTS for the course.
2. Completing the course by 'distance learning' (extra assignments, papers etc) in the month of January, receiving 7.5 ECTS for the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Gain knowledge about current research themes and methods in mineralogy and isotope geochemistry
• Learn how to apply quantitative models to metamorphic and mineralogical questions.
• Gain awareness of analytical techniques available to study mineralogical research questions.
• Acquire the ability to understand and critically examine scientific literature in this field.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Short recap of: Mineralogy and crystallography including bonding and electronic structure of solids, point and space groups for crystal symmetry, surface to bulk properties of materials
• Introduction to advanced analytical tools including electron beam techniques, spectroscopic methods, synchotron methods.

• Applications will be illustrated with case histories. Examples are: interfacial processes during mineral weathering, biomineralization, hydrothermal systems in solid Earth, industrial metamorphism including CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste disposal and unconventional hydrocarbons. Where possible external speakers will be invited to present cutting edge research currently conducted in different industrial sectors to study mineralogical questions.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173006,2016,Earth Resources (mineral and petroleum resources),English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. O. Plümper', 'dr. W.W.W. Beekman', 'Various teachers']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>By the end of the course, the student:

column2: • will have obtained in-depth understanding of concepts, tools and techniques applied to predict the distribution of various natural resources, including ore deposits and surface mineral resources.
<li>will have learned about ore-forming processes in general, and in more detail about:

column3: • ancient and modern volcanogenic and sediment-hosted massive sulphides
• gold deposits and formation of gold veins

column2: • will have become familiar with several modern exploration methods commonly used for the detection of mineral resources located in the shallow and/or deep subsurface.
• will have become familiar with and learned how to assess European strategies for nuclear waste disposal and associated geo-political issues
• will have obtained experience in applying relevant knowledge and skills to case studies concerning Earth Resources;
• will have developed skills for pursuing a career in the Resources industry.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In our society there is a continuous demand of natural resources, e.g. in the energy, food, metal industry and construction sectors. These resources can be divided, from an economical perspective, into two main groups: petroleum and mineral resources. This particular course focuses on the geological, exploration, (sustainable) exploitation and (socio-) economical aspects of the most important mineral resources present in the deep and shallow subsurface. Petroleum resources (coal, oil and gas) are treated in the (M-profile) MSc courses Reflection Seismics and Petroleum Systems (GEO4-1441).

column2: <li>The first part of the course will start with an introduction in Natural Resources, covering topics such as global distribution of Earth resources, demands, reserves, and the role of geologists in exploration and exploitation. Subsequently, a series of lectures and assignments will be given on:

column3: • occurrence and exploitation of metal ores (e.g. bulk industrial metals, rare earth metals)
• uranium deposits; disposal strategies on nuclear waste
• global salt resources; mining of salt in The Netherlands

column2: <li>The second part of the course will focus on exploration methods for mineral resources. This will include lectures and assignments on:

column3: • use of satellite images to remotely explore mineral resources
• geophysical exploration methods, in particular gravity and geomagnetic surveying for mineral resources

column1: During the first and second part of the course, student couples also will have to write an essay on a self-chosen topic related to the sustainable exploration of mineral resources (instructions and a list of possible topics will be provided at the start of the course). The essays will be presented in the last week of the course.

The main component of the course is designed as a combination between lectures and some direct application of the lectured principles in practical exercises. Students will be informed per lecture about the key papers, character of the practical exercises or assignments.

The second course component involves student couples writing and presenting an essay on a self-chosen topic related to mineral or hydrocarbon resources (a list of possible topics will be provided at the start of the course). Moreover, each student couple will also assess the essays of two other student couples and prepare critical questions for the oral presentations. Students will receive instructions about the expected content and style of the essays at the start of the course.
During the course, the students are expected to:

column2: • actively participate in practical’s and complete all assignments
• actively participate in class discussions, by asking well-thought questions

column1: Most weeks, there will be a mix of lectures and class assignments on both Tuesday and Thursday. However, depending on the guest lecturer, the actual learning activities might change from session to session.</body>
