Essentials of Business and Entrepreneurship is the first course of the Minor Entrepreneurship. After completing this course students can continue with Venture Marketing (EC2VM) and Financial Accounting and External Accountability (ECB1IBE), followed by either the course Corporate Entrepreneurship and Innovation (ECB3CEI) or an internship (Entrepreneurship and Innovation – ECB2IEI).
For more information on business and entrepreneurship education: http://www.uu.nl/entrepreneurship
At the end of the course the student:

column2: • Understands the phenomenon of entrepreneurship from an academic perspective;
• Is able to discuss the entrepreneurial process and apply the literature to real cases;
• Is more comfortable in dealing with incomplete information and uncertainty for the purpose of assessing a business opportunity;
• Has increased his/her cooperation skills by working together in small teams and has improved his/her skills of effectively transferring information by presenting his/her work to others;
• Has learned to test and validate assumptions and develop a business model;
• Is able to write and interpret a compelling business plan.

column1: The course is offered as a combination of interactive lectures and workshops.
Students are expected to be present and well prepared at 80% of the meetings and have to hand in all individual and group assignments on time through Blackboard.

This is an intensive course, which requires the average student about 20 hours of work per week for individual assignments and group work including contact moments. It is not advised to follow this course if one wants to complete more than two courses in one period.
A score of 60 ECTS is recommended.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: At the end of the course the student:

column5: has knowledge of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying psychiatric (e.g. schizophrenia, addiction, autism and ADHD) and neurological diseases (e.g. epilepsy and Huntington”s disease);
can formulate a research question and describe experiments to address this research question in the field of neuroscience;
can present and defend a research question in front of peers;
has an overview of research in the field of neuroscience at the UMC Utrecht.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Ramakers, Adan, Burbach, Pasterkamp, De Graan, Kas; UMC Utrecht, Brain Center Rudolf Magnus, Department of Translational Neuroscience
The aim of the course is to provide sufficient background in molecular and cellular neuroscience to understand mechanisms underlying psychiatiric and neurological diseases.

This intense two weeks course is intended for non-neuroscience master students who want to get more background into neuroscience.  The lectures during the course cover a broad range of neuroscience topics from gene to neurological disease and include neuro-anatomy, neurodevelopment, synaptic plasticity, neurogenetics and diseases such as Epilepsy, Anorexia nervosa, Obesity and Parkinsons disease and are given by experts from the Rudolf Magnus Institute of Neurosciences. During the afternoons the students will work in couples on an assignment on a neurological disease. This assignment will results in a scientific presentation on the disease, which will discuss all aspects covered in the lectures, ranging from clinical symptoms and treatment, to molecular and cellular mechanisms, to genetic studies and genes involved. These presentations will be held on the last Friday during a symposium.
Parts of Neuroscience (Purves et al., Sinauer Ass.Inc., Sunderland, Massachusetts, 4e editie, 2004 (ISBN 978-0-87893-697-7)) and recent reviews and original articles.
Apply at least 1 week before start of course.  Register via the study guide. The maximum number of participants is 40.
Mandatory for students in own Master’s programme:
For BOD students. Four courses have to be chosen out of the six non-mandatory BOD-courses.
Optional for students in other GSLS Master’s programme:

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: By the end of the course, the student will:

column5: have a general understanding of  concepts and methods needed to examine key processes in estuarine ecosystems;
be able to perform mathematical analyses to better understand these concepts and methods;
be able to critically read (understanding the main message, interpreting the results, recognizing the strengths and the weaknesses of) a scientific paper.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The course introduces, discusses and applies concepts and methods with regard to key processes that structure estuarine ecosystems. Hereto, we will discuss current thoughts and findings based on recent peer-reviewed scientific papers from international journals on estuarine ecology together with the authors. Students will perform simple analyses (in R) linked to the selected papers to develop a better understanding of the paper and of a feeling of some of the practical aspects of ecological research in estuarine systems. The course also includes a one-day visit to the Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, where the students will design, perform and analyse the results of an ecological experiment in a marine testing environment.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173308,2016,Ethical Theory & Moral Practice,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. W. F. Kalf'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completion of the course the student:
1 is able to distinguish (at least) three different types of approaches in applied ethics and reflect on the merits and pitfalls of each approach;

2 have in depth knowledge of and can outline ethical theoretical positions (like utilitarianism, virtue ethics and Kantianism, but also on pragmatism and coherentism) and the main criticisms and advantages of such positions in the context of applied ethics;

3 is able to distinguish at least one epistemological and meta-ethical aspect within each approach in applied ethics (eg with regards to the status of moral intuitions, moral judgments, value pluralism and relativism);

4 is able to determine their own position in the debate on approaches in applied ethics and how (normative) theories relate to practical cases in applied ethics. This shows both in oral presentations as in written assignments.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This graduate course in normative ethics is being taught with a focus on the relation between ethical theories in contexts of applied ethics. We will start the discussion with a basic model as presented by Arras in his entry in the Stanford encyclopedia of philosophy. In the field of bioethics (or applied ethics as we rather prefer) we can distinguish ‘High Theory’, ‘Anti-Theory’ and ‘Midlevel’ approaches. We will study examples of each type and discuss what is attractive and less attractive of each approach. In this context of theory-practice related issues, we will also deepen our knowledge on epistemological and meta-ethical discussions (like the status of moral intuitions, the status of moral judgments, value pluralism and relativism) insofar as these are related to certain approaches (or are overarching to them). This course focuses more on theoretical reflection on the relation between theory and practice, which will help to understand the methods and tools that are being developed within certain fields of applied ethics that will be discussed in the second course, namely Practice, Tools and Philosophy.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171785,2016,Ethical and Political Implications of Human Nature,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. H.C. Sauer', 'dr. N. van Steenbergen', 'dr. R van Broekhoven']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The     aim     of     the     course     is     to     gain     a     solid     grasp     of     the     current     literature     on     the     topics     covered,     as     well     as     further     training     in     the     critical     analysis     of     arguments     made     in     current     debates     and     the     development     of     an     independent     point     of     view     within     these     debates.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Approaches     to     ethics     and     politics     are     built     on     a     variety     of     assumptions     about     human     nature.     Those     who     see     human     beings     as     essentially     irrational,     selfish,     aggressive,     and     short-sighted     support     political     systems     and     ethical     theories     that     differ     markedly     from     what     is     defended     by     those     who     emphasize     human     autonomy,     rationality,     compassion,     and     dignity.     In     this     course,     we     examine     how     conceptions     of     human     nature     frame     contemporary     debates     in     ethics     and     politics     regarding,     for     example,     the     conditions     for     a     well-functioning     democracy,     the     psychologically     realistic     limits     on     moral     responsibility,     the     appropriateness     of     state     paternalism,     the     permissibility     of     enhancement,     and     the     legitimacy     of     attributing     rights     only     to     humans.     Attention     will     also     be     paid     to     the     role     that     social     practices     and     institutions     can     play     in     supporting     or     undermining     the     human     capabilities     presupposed     by     the     various     public     policies     advocated     in     these     debates.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192840,2016,Ethics,English,University College Roosevelt,,[],,
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171779,2016,Ethics and Health,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['drs. C.J. Kessler', 'S. Vermeulen']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
-gains       insight       in       imporant       ethical       debates       in       the       context       of       medical       ethics       and       health       care
-is able       to       apply       ethical       concepts       and       theories       to       cases       in       the       field
-gets an       overview       of       developments       in       applied       ethics
-reflects     on     her     own     position     to     relevant     topics
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In     the     20th     century,     the     field     of     applied     ethics     emerged     first     and     foremost     in     the     medical     field.     This     course     will     serve     both     as     an     introduction     to     'classical     medical     ethics'     and     show     how     other     fields     of     applied     ethics     have     developed     since.     It     will     cover     classic     debates     on     patient-physician     relationship,     leading     principles     in     health     care,     core     issues     in     the     field     in     the     past     and     present.     The     course     will     combine     theoretical     concepts,     classic     literature     and     current     debates     in     the     field     of     health     care     ethics.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173315,2016,Ethics and Public Policy,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['Docent nog onbekend/To be announced', 'dr. S.P. Riley']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3:   is able to identify ethical dilemmas that policymakers may face in dealing with issues of individual liberty.
  is able to identify ethical dilemmas that policymakers may face in dealing with issues of public safety and other public goods.
  can analyse these dilemmas combining theoretical knowledge and practical contexts.
  is senstive to dynamics in administrative contexts of governance and is able to make beneficial ethical analysis to these contexts.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In this course, you will examine different topics involving ethical dilemmas in the context of policymaking, like those related to individual liberties and public goods. We will examine questions like: How do individual rights need to be balanced with the security needs of the state? Where do the rights of individuals end and the rights of society as a whole begin? What legal and ethical constraints should be placed on international trade?

Each of these dilemmas may be examined under different theoretical frameworks (e.g. Utilitarian, Rights-based, Virtue, Justice) sometimes resulting in different outcomes. You will see which frameworks policymakers, officials, and lawmakers tend to apply to different types of issues and circumstances. You will  learn to assess whether these frameworks are appropriate for all types of dilemma’s policymakers may face by making a group analysis on one particular topic.
Guest speakers will highlight state of the art debate. These debates can include terroism, refugee-issues, climate change, nudging, biotechnology and big data.
Career orientation  Students will get acquainted with policy oriented careers in practical philosophy.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174925,2016,Ethics and Religion,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. C. Baumgartner'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: describe and analyze important ethical theories,
understand and evaluate the complex relationships between philosophical and religious ethics in different historical and cultural contexts,
identify, analyze and evaluate concrete moral issues,
articulate, examine and refine their own views on complex moral issues

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course offers a survey of ethical ideas and theories in philosophical and religious schools of thought and traditions respectively; beyond this it addresses specific topical moral issues in the fields of bioethics, political ethics, and environmental ethics.

Ethics considers what is right and wrong and good and bad in human actions, analyzing questions such as how we ought to live, what kind of persons we should be, which aims are worth striving for, and what obligations we have to others. This course combines three different approaches by a) studying the history of philosophical and religious ideas, b) investigating systematical and conceptual issues (e.g. virtue, happiness, justice, love & friendship, dignity, moral rights and duties, compassion and other emotions), and c) analyzing concrete moral problems from different perspectives.

Major currents of philosophical and religious ethics will be represented in primary sources from Buddhism, Christianity, and Islam, and in texts by key thinkers such as Confucius, Mencius, Aristotle, Stoic philosophers, Augustine, Thomas Aquinas, Kant, Mill, Nietzsche and others. We will analyze influential theories and principles such as deontology, consequentialism, the golden rule, divine command theory, neighborly love, natural law theory, ahimsa or dao. The theoretical framework of rival ethical theories will be applied to exploring the complexities of debates about concrete moral problems related to, e.g. poverty and affluence, war and ‘humanitarian interventions’, animal welfare, and moral problems concerning climate change and future generations.

The course is part of both the philosophy track and the religious studies track. At the same time it should appeal to Social Science majors and to students with an interest in morally relevant issues (sustainability, biomedicine etc.).

Class meetings focus on discussion of selected readings (esp. primary texts) and issues related to them. The Instructor presents background information and related views, questions, or objections that are explored during class. Students are supposed to prepare the texts prior to the class for which they are assigned.

There are short written assignments, e.g. summarizing an argument or illustrating it in the form of a graph, formulating objections against an argument in the text, preparing an annotated bibliography etc.

Students are stimulated to discuss and evaluate the ideas that the texts present, and to propose alternatives. There are instructor-guided but open class discussions; students are supposed to actively engage with the material and to actively participate in class.
Students are responsible for the preparation of an essay, a brief presentation, and an exam.
The course is a core course in the Religious Studies Track as well as in the Philosophy Track. The course alternates with UCHUMPHI25: Philosophical Views on Humans and Gods.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173319,2016,Ethics of Institutions,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. I.A.M. Robeyns'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: -           can explain to his peers what institutions are, and how institutional ethics relates to, and interacts with, other forms of ethical analysis;
-           is able to identify when an ethical issue requires an institutional approach, rather than an individual focus;
-           is able to make an ethical analysis of an institution or institutional change;
-           is able to defend his or her own normative position regarding the ethical desirability of an institution;
-           can show in a few domains concrete ethical analyses of institutions and lucidly explain this analysis to his peers.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course aims to give the students a graduate-level introduction in the ethics of institutions. It aims to equip them to make a basic ethical analysis of an institution, and provide them with the knowledge of the relevant literature. The course also aides the students to develop their own normative position in the landscape of ethical theories, or to strengthen the critical understanding of a position that they may already be endorsing.
Throughout the course, examples of different types of institutions will be examined, hence from medical, economic, social, political, etc. ethics.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171767,2016,Ethics, Globalization and Sustainability",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. J.P.M. Philips', 'dr. M.A. van den Hoven', 'dr. R van Broekhoven', 'S. Vermeulen']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: - gains insight in imporant ethical debates in the context of social and political philosophy, more particularly with regards to justice debates.
-gets core knowledge of Rawls, Walzer, Pogge, Nussbaum and others
-application of core concepts to debates on globalization and sustainability.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: On a global scale , wealth, health  and life opportunities are unfairly distributed. Philosophers have emphasized that this unfairness gives the affluent a moral duty to help the worst-off (Singer, Cullity), others tried to formulate basic principles for a fair society (Rawls, Walzer). Some argue that institutions cause unfairness (Pogge) and should change. In this course, basic theories of justice and key ethical principles (like precautionary principle, equality) are discussed and related to relevant topics in current society. Climate change and poverty will be particulary addressed. </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171794,2016,Ethics, Science and Integrity",English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. H.L.C. Logister'],,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- gains       insight       in       imporant       ethical       debates       in       the       context       of       research

Recent     debates     on     research     integrity     will     be     addressed,     but     moreover,     the     core     characteristics     of     research,     of     value-assumptions     in     the     academy,     technology     assessment     and     responsibiity     for     the     development     of     research     is     being     discussed.     We     can     learn     from     controversial     debates     in     the     past     and     present     (e.g.     biotechnology)
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176068,2016,Ethics in Biomedical Sciences,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['drs. C.J. Kessler'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het biomedisch onderzoek kent belangrijke ethische componenten en roept ook steeds vaker ethische vragen en discussies in de samenleving op. Voorbeelden zijn de discussie rondom het (genetisch) modificeren van dieren en mensen, transgenese en de vraag wie eigenaar zou moeten zijn van menselijk lichaamsmateriaal voor onderzoeksdoeleinden. Ook zaken als integriteit van onderzoekers en fraude in de wetenschappelijke praktijk hebben alles met ethiek te maken.

Ethische kwesties rondom biomedisch onderzoek krijgen steeds meer aandacht in de media en daarbij valt op dat de onderzoekers rechtstreeks worden aangesproken om verantwoording af te leggen over hun handelen. Het is van belang dat wetenschappers zich bewust zijn van de ethische aspecten van hun werk. Bovendien is het belangrijk dat zij in staat zijn om die ethische aspecten te betrekken bij hun beslissingen en daardoor hun keuzes kunnen verantwoorden met houdbare argumenten.

De keuzecursus ‘Ethiek’ wordt gedoceerd door medewerkers van het Ethiek Instituut. De eerste weken zullen een algemene inleiding in de ethiek inhouden. Naast termen, concepten en de belangrijkste uitgangspunten, zal er ook zeer sterk gefocust worden op vaardigheden, zoals het herkennen van ethische problemen, het opstellen van argumentatieschema’s en het leren beoordelen van ethische argumenten. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan academische vaardigheden, zoals het leren houden van een presentatie en het schrijven van een essay.

In de weken na de inleiding zullen diverse thema’s uit de (biomedische) ethiek de revue passeren, bijvoorbeeld neuroethiek, psychofarmacologie en dierethiek. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de belangrijkste ethische theorieën, waaronder het utilisme, deugdethiek en kantiaanse ethiek.
Na afloop van dit blok is de student in staat:

column2: • zelfstandig morele problemen te herkennen en te benoemen;
• ethische vraagstukken die zich in de praktijk van het biomedisch onderzoek voordoen te benoemen en de belangrijkste morele argumenten die daarbij een rol spelen weer te geven;
• een beeld te schetsen van de positie van biomedische onderzoekers in het maatschappelijke krachtenveld en hun rol in het publieke debat over wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen;
• de plaats van wetenschappelijk onderzoek in de samenleving te beschrijven.

column1: Na afloop van dit blok is de student in staat:

column2: • een essay te schrijven over een ethisch onderwerp;

column1: Na afloop van dit blok is de student in staat:

column2: • een beargumenteerde mening te geven over ethische problemen uit de praktijk van het biomedisch onderzoek;
• een onderbouwde visie te formuleren over de specifieke morele verantwoordelijkheid van biomedisch onderzoekers.

column1: Dit blok bestaat uit interactieve hoorcolleges, werkgroepen en zelfstudie. De totale contacttijd bedraagt 44 uur.

column2: • “Ethiek in praktijk”, L.L.E. Bolt, M.F. Verweij, J.J.M. van Delden, 7de druk (2010), ISBN 978-90-2323-835-5

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176131,2016,Ethics of Animal Use,Dutch,Faculty of Veterinary Medicine,,['prof. dr. F.L.B. Meijboom'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Verdieping en verbreding kennis en vaardigheden ethiek, in de zin dat studenten uitgedaagd worden om op theoretisch en praktisch niveau ethische en maatschappelijke vragen te doordenken en aan te pakken. </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Het betreft een verbreding, omdat het de mogelijkheid biedt om thema´s die niet, of in zeer beperkte mate, in het andere onderwijs aanbod komen in dit vak te presenteren. Hierbij gaat het zowel om een uitbreiding van dierethische als om beroepsethisch vraagstukken.

Thema’s waar de dierenarts met grote regelmaat mee te maken krijgt (b.v. Het al of niet doodspuiten van gezonde stierkalveren, de beslissing om te castreren als dat ten koste gaat van ongeboren kittens, de wijze van advisering als het gaat om weidegang en huisvesting van melkvee, maar ook bredere thema’s als de noodzaak van een ethische afweging bij ruimen Q-koorts en de regulering van antibioticagebruik.) of waar hij/zij op wordt aangesproken vanuit de samenleving of de overheid.

Eerder verworven kennis en vaardigheden op het terrein van ethiek wordt gemobiliseerd, verdiept en toegepast op concrete maatschappelijke vraagstukken, nieuwe kennis op het terrein van ethische theorie, morele oordeelsvorming, en de morele status van dieren die nodig zijn om als dierenarts met een concrete (klinische en maatschappelijke) ethische vraagstukken om te kunnen gaan worden opgedaan en nieuwe vaardigheden die de professional in staat stellen om – met inzicht van theoretische achtergronden – te komen tot praktische beslissingen worden ontwikkeld en daar wordt mee geoefend. Je leert actief te reflecteren op de eigen (veterinaire) rol en verantwoordelijkheid in de te behandelen maatschappelijke en ethische vraagstukken.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171769,2016,Ethics, Human Rights, and Religious Tolerance",Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. C. Baumgartner'],,"Course goals
- kan morele problemen, die binnen een pluralistische maatschappij van belang zijn, herkennen;
- heeft inzicht in de rol die religie(s) bij onderwerpen op het gebied van mensenrechten en tolerantie kunnen spelen;
- kan met behulp van verschillende ethische begrippen en concepties de genoemde morele problemen analyseren en beoordelen.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Een maatschappij als Nederlandwil het mogelijk maken       dat       mensen       met       verschillende       wereldbeschouwelijke       of       religieuze       overtuigingen       vreedzaam       met       elkaar       samenleven.       De       vrijheid       om       naar       eigen       inzicht       waarden       en       ideeën       van       het       goede       leven       te       realiseren,       geldt       daarbij       als       een       groot       goed.       Maar       dit       pluralisme       kent       haar       eigen       problemen.

Verschillende religieuze en wereldbeschouwelijke overtuigingen en praktijken bestaan niet noodzakelijk vreedzaam naast elkaar. Daarom wordt het onderwerp tolerantie steeds belangrijker. Maar wat betekent eigenlijk precies tolerantie? Zijn we verplicht tolerant te zijn? Waar liggen de grenzen van tolerantie? En wat is de rol van religie in dit discours? Deze rol lijkt ambivalent. Enerzijds wordt religie gezien als een conflicthaard in multiculturele maatschappijen. Dit is duidelijk als men naar de verschillende vormen van religieus fundamentalisme kijkt. Anderzijds zijn er belangrijke auteurs die van religie een substantiële bijdrage verwachten om problemen zowel in multiculturele maatschappijen als op mondiaal vlak op te lossen. In de cursus leren de studenten eerst belangrijke grondbegrippen en distincties kennen. De grootste aandacht zal gegeven worden aan de onderwerpen mensenrechten en tolerantie. Daarbij worden verschillende praktische problemen onderzocht, die expliciet met religie verbonden zijn (bijv. godsdienstvrijheid, vrijheid van meningsuiting, of scheiding van kerk en staat).

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171448,2016,Ethnic Literatures and Cultures in the U.S.,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. A.L. Poletti', 'dr. J.E.M. Hoorenman']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to provide students with in-depth     knowledge     and     understanding     of     the     literature     and     culture     of     one     of     the     main     ethnic     groups     in     the     United     States,     i.e.     Native     Americans,     African     Americans,     Asian     Americans,     Latin     Americans,     or     Jewish     Americans.     Students     who     complete     this     course     will     be     able     to     identify     key     aspects     of     the     experience     of     the     ethnic     group     in     question     and     analyze     the     literary     means     by     which     these     are     portrayed.     Building     on     course     readings     and     class     discussions     of     primary     and     secondary     texts     students     will     be     prepared     to     conduct     further     independent     research     to     produce     original     scholarly     papers     on     (a)     literary     work(s)     by     (an)     author(s)     from     the     ethnic     group     studied     in     the     course.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will focus on the rich literary tradition of one of the main American ethnic groups in its historical, social, and cultural context. Among the questions that will come up for discussion are: What is the relation between the writers of the minority group in question and ""mainstream"" American literature, and how has this evolved over time? How are the relations between American society at large and this minority group portrayed in the literature of the latter? How do inter-generational relations within the minority group figure in its literature? And how do these minority writers employ linguistic and literary strategies as means of dramatizing their ethnic experience within the broader traditions of the dominant culture?

Please note that this year the course will offer students an introduction to Jewish American fiction as a window onto the Jewish experience in the United States. The focus in the first part of the course will be on the immigrant experience in works by writers of the first generation, such as Abraham Cahan and Anzia Yezierska; the movement from the periphery into the mainstream of American literature that began in the 1940s with the appearance of post-immigrant writers such as Delmore Schwartz, Saul Bellow, and Bernard Malamud; and the experience of marginality in the work of these generations of writers. The second half of the course will focus on fiction by younger Jewish American writers, such as Yael Goldstein Love, Thane Rosenbaum, Tova Mirvis, Elisa Albert, Edward Schwarzschild, and Binnie Kirshenbaum, with specific attention being paid to, among other things, the relation between the experience of rootlessness in the work of these writers and that of their predecessors, to Jewish American fiction in the context of multiculturalism, and to postethnic theory and some of the questions it raises regarding the ways in which Jewish identity is portrayed in recent Jewish American writing.

Students who are required to return to their home university by the end of December, are allowed to choose an early exit option. Students must always make individual arrangements with the course coordinator. In general, there are two options that can be facilitated:
1. Finishing the course before Christmas break, receiving 5 ECTS for the course.
2. Completing the course by 'distance learning' (extra assignments, papers etc) in the month of January, receiving 7.5 ECTS for the course.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In this course we focus on a comparative analysis of the manifestations and causes of ethnic conflicts, racism and nationalism across different nations and ethnic groups. We address these questions from several theoretical angles in order to model the individual and contextual conditions of ethnic conflicts, racism and nationalism. With regard to academic skills, the focus will be on comparing and synthesizing different theories, critically assessing the merits of theoretical and empirical studies, posing new research questions and deducing testable hypotheses, and oral presentations and writing skills by means of a theoretical paper.</body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course we investigate different types of ethnic conflicts, both in     its     manifest     forms     (violence,     discrimination,     protests)     as     well     as     latent     forms     of     conflicts     (racism,     nationalism,     and     negative     intergroup     attitudes).     We     explore     theoretical     perspectives     from     different     disciplines     such     as     sociology,     social-psychology,     and     political     sciences     to     understand     the     causes     of     ethnic     conflicts.     A     number     of     explanations     will     be     examined,     such     as     social     identity     theory,     realistic     group     conflict     theory     and     political     factors.     A     special     focus     will     be     on     the     multi-level     analysis     of     these     phenomena,     taking     into     account     individual,     meso     and     macro     level     factors.     The     contribution     of     each     of     these     causes     and     how     they     interplay     with     one     another     will     be     examined     across     various     contexts,     both     within     and     outside     of     the     European     context.     First,     we     examine     prejudice     and     discrimination     among     the     majority     population     towards     immigrants     and     ethnic     minorities.     Furthermore,     we     examine     the     stances     of     immigrants     and     ethnic     minorities     towards     the     host     society     and     how     they     strive     for     more     rights     and     equality.     Finally,     we     examine     how     intergroup     tensions     and     conflicts     may     be     reduced     or     resolved.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: During this phase of the master’s research students collect empirical data by conducting fieldwork independently. The fieldwork may also be part of a research internship at or in collaboration with an external institution (NGOs etc.).
In the reporting phase of the master’s research students are trained to analyze and interpret their collected data and to report these in a solid scientific thesis.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: On the basis of an accepted research proposal that has been prepared in the course ‘Ethnographic methods and research design’, the second semester of the program compromises the actual ethnographic fieldwork and data collection phase (approximately fourteen weeks). During the fieldwork phase, you keep in contact with your supervisor. In several field reports you discuss the progression of data collection, and your experiences in the field and with research participants. At the end of the fieldwork period they start with the organization and encoding of the empirical data.

After you have completed your fieldwork, you will start with preparing and writing your M.Sc. thesis. The main task that needs to go hand-in-hand with writing is the combination of your empirical, first-hand research with secondary data, and finally with the larger, more general theoretical questions you set out to answer or the theoretical debate you are addressing.

In a series of meetings with your supervisor, you will demonstrate your progress in writing their M.Sc. thesis, and discuss how to use your empirical knowledge and secondary materials to develop broader interpretations about your study in a meaningful relationship with the theoretical frame of your research question.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170886,2016,Ethnographic Methods and Research Design,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. ir. Y. van der Pijl'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: To learn, understand and apply new theoretical approaches and concepts about ethnographic methods and research design:  participant observation, sensory ethnography, digital mediation, subjectivity, reflexivity, positionality, accountability, scientific integrity.
To analyze both academic and societal debates about the role and aims of social representations (in ethnography, visual anthropology, media and digital ethnography).
Developing an understanding of the arguments at hand as well as one’s own critical methodological orientation.
To learn to report on the methodological tools and ethnographic projects presented in the course in a scientific way (using argumentation, organization, and analysis).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Fieldwork is the defining research strategy of anthropology and demands solid preparation. This course is devoted to the practicalities of actually ‘doing’ ethnographic fieldwork in real world settings. The course is dedicated to an understanding of the practice of fieldwork and focusses on methods, in particular participant observation, visual and media ethnography, and writing and processing ethnographic field notes and audiovisual materials. Participant observation is dealt with not so much as a formal protocol but as a way to gather contextual information that can help in the recognition of topics for investigation, in identifying potential research participants for subsequent interviewing or filming, and in building rapport and accountability in the fieldwork setting. Students are taught how to gather, classify and organize their field notes, their audio-visual materials, and to turn observations into ethnographic "data", paying close attention to gaps in their contextual knowledge. The importance and complexity of language and media is also investigated, by emphasizing how the social and cognitive relationship between researcher and research participants shapes their inter-personal communication as well as the resulting ethnographic representations.

Part of a solid preparation includes the development of research skills. Scientific knowledge about people’s lives, decisions, interactions, cultural models, and practices is acquired to an important degree through verbal communication, but increasingly also through media exchanges and audio-visual, digital forms of data creation and dissemination. Conversations, dialogues and interviews are complex speech forms, which require a thorough understanding of the social interaction among the interlocutors. On the other hand, self-representation through social networks as well as different degrees of familiarity with interactive media technologies can feature substantially in the set-up of field relations. Consequently, our classes will deal with participant observation, interview, visual anthropology and digital ethnography skills. In each case, different kinds of practical and ethical dilemmas in doing fieldwork will be addressed.

Anthropologists continually focus on cultural diversity and differences based on ethnicity, class, gender, age, and health. This course will equip students with the knowledge and skills to evaluate these facets of life and their interrelationships. Besides ‘traditional’ anthropological methods and techniques (fieldwork, participatory observation, and qualitative interviews), this course will explore innovative methodologies in the areas of reflexive and sensory ethnography, ethnographic film, and digital ethnography. Students will learn to articulate their ethical dilemmas, accountabilities and social responsibility.

During the course, students will use the insights derived from course classes to write their research proposal. They will complete drafts of their proposals by the end of the course in consultation with their supervisors with whom they will have regular meetings.

column5: Being able to carry out empirical field research according to anthropological methods, with a particular emphasis on qualitative empirical methods..
Applying anthropological theories to international discussions in the discipline to concrete empirical research questions.
Skilfully employing qualitative empirical methods to generate data necessary to examine and answer the hypothesis or research questions.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Ethnographic field research is a key component of the CASTOR research master program. The research project will allow students to train and enhance their empirical research capabilities by applying anthropological field research methods and techniques. The research project will be based on a detailed research proposal written in course CASTOR-5 Ethnographic Fieldwork and Research Design. Students demonstrate through five months of ethnographic fieldwork their competence in the application of relevant scientific theories and concepts, their knowledge of the research area and cultural context, and their application of anthropological insights and methodological skills to a research topic.

Students will be in principle free to choose their subject, approach and location of research, as long as they fall within the general scope of CASTOR. The methodological approach needs to be transparent, and focused on participant observation as the central method of anthropology. Permission to start the research project will depend on approval of the research proposal, and on a positive assessment by the supervisor and program director about its feasibility and safety in the chosen country or location.

Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy implies in this course the handing in on time of progress reports and the final report. Overtime submissions will be evaluated by the fieldwork supervisor and the coordinator on a case-to-case basis.</body>

column5: Has a profound understanding of Animal Welfare as a scientific concept.
Has a profound understanding of (neuro)ethological concepts that are important for the investigation and evaluation of animal welfare.
Has a profound understanding of factors that may contribute to the development of behavioural problems of animals kept under human care.
Has a profound understanding of limits of behavioural and physiological adaptation and its underlying neurophysiological and ethological mechanisms.

Has a profound understanding of how fundamental knowledge can be applied in order to a) evaluate animal welfare, b) design appropriate housing environments and management procedures for animals kept under human care and c) diagnose behavioural and animal welfare problems of animals kept under human care.
Has a profound understanding of factors that are relevant for the design of experiments and procedures used to investigate animal welfare or relevant mechanisms underlying welfare-related questions.
Is able to use and apply (neuro)ethological concepts in order to develop and design research on animal welfare related topics.
Is able to contribute to the public debate in the field of animal welfare by using sound scientific arguments.
Is able to evaluate animal welfare of animals kept under human care and to substantiate that evaluation by scientific arguments.
Is able to understand and possibly diagnose behavioural problems of animals kept under human care.
Is able to make ethograms for research regarding animal welfare.
Is able to translate public questions in the field of animal welfare in terms of sound scientific research questions.

- Animal welfare – as a scientific concept
- Recent developments in farm animal husbandry systems

Students from the master programme Neuroscience & Cognition of the Utrecht University are expected to have completed the general Fundamentals Course (15 ECTS). Other students are required to have a demonstrable BSc-level knowledge of neuroscience or behavioral biology.

column3: Doel is alle eerstejaars studenten op een gelijk kennisniveau te brengen als solide basis voor de exact georiënteerde vakken in het bachelor curriculum Aardwetenschappen. Voorwaarden hiervoor zijn het verwerven van een gedegen basiskennis in wis- en natuurkunde, en het beheersen van methodieken voor de analyse en het oplossen van wiskundige en fysische problemen.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Een goede basiskennis van wis- en natuurkunde is onmisbaar voor alle disciplines in de Aardwetenschappen. Of het nou gaat om de korrelgrootte-verdeling van zandkorrels in een rivierbedding, vervormingen en deformaties in gesteente, of de voortplanting van seismische golven na een aardbeving.

Tijdens de cursus worden afwisselend wiskundige methodieken en fysische principes behandeld, en hoe deze gezamenlijk gebruikt worden voor het analyseren en oplossen van vraagstukken. Wiskundige onderwerpen die besproken worden zijn o.a. functies, goniometrie, limieten, differentiëren, functie-onderzoek en statistiek. Natuurkundige onderwerpen die de revue passeren zijn o.a. klassieke mechanica, vloeistofmechanica en behoudswetten. Zowel de wiskundige als fysische onderwerpen die behandeld worden zijn grotendeels, maar niet volledig, bekend van de middelbare school. In deze cursus worden die (deels) herhaald en verder afgemaakt.
De cursus is ingangseis voor: Veldwerk 1.

Dit is de casuscursus van het Verdiepingspakket Europa

Rond 500 verdween het West-Romeinse keizerrijk en begon er een lang proces van transformatie, waarin Europa zoals we dat nu kennen haar eerste contouren begon te krijgen. Deze cursus gaat in op deze transformatie: waar kwamen opeens de barbaarse koninkrijken vandaan, en wat voor rol heeft het christendom als integratieve kracht gespeeld? Wat bleef er eigenlijk over van de Romeinse erfenis, en wat was er nu wezenlijk nieuw?</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: the student has knowledge and understanding of the legal aspects of European competition law.
the student is capable of resolving complex cases in the field of European competition law.
the student is able to analyze the interaction between law and economics in the application of European competition law and to recognize the societal context in European competition law.
the student is able to critically review and apply concepts of European competition law.
the student is aware of the opportunities within the field of competition law and has experienced the application of the law in practice.
the student is able to present and discuss, concisely and precisely, points of view on a competition law case or question.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course aims to provide in-depth knowledge of the main aspects of European Competition law. Students should be able to apply this knowledge to a given set of concrete facts by solving complex competition law cases which closely resemble actual cases in competition practice. In this course competition law is placed the context of the economics-based application of competition law. Attention is given to the wider debate on the role of competition and competition regulation in society. Principles relating to the concept of competition and the market principle are studied and discussed. The concepts that are central to competition law such as the concept of undertaking, the cartel prohibition, the prohibition on the abuse of a dominant position and merger control are examined and applied to concrete sets of facts. The case law of the relevant Courts is discussed and procedures, enforcement mechanisms and issues relating to proof in competition cases are presented. The course focuses primarily on European competition law, but the relationship between European competition law and national competition law is addressed.

In the lectures, the doctrine on the particular topic for that week is presented and discussed. These will provide the students with various viewpoints and opinions, also on the place of competition (law) in society. Students are invited to participate actively in the lectures through questions addressed to the audience. The aim of the lectures is to provide further clarification of the information provided in the course materials, so that students are well prepared for active participation in the case-solving seminars. During the extra lectures specific attention will be given to the practical application of competition law. Some of these extra lectures provide for a more specified aspect of a general theme, others provide an in depth discussion of recent or actual (non-decided) cases. For these extra lectures practitioners from leading law firms, members of the judiciary and/or economists working in the field of competition law will be invited and students are given the opportunity to engage in a discussion with these practitioners. These extra lectures will thus provide students with an opportunity to practice discussion- and networking skills and provide them with insight on what competition law means in practice. During the seminars in this course the students' case-solving capacities will be exercised, as a significant part of the competition law practice is aimed at complex case solving. Students will elaborate on specific case-questions, or will solve cases in small working groups in the classroom during the seminar. The cases relate to issues of European competition law such as horizontal and vertical agreements, the Merger Control Regulation, the relationship between Competition and the State, proof and procedures and abuse of dominance. Most case questions are (based on) real cases, and actual, non-decided cases, will be discussed during the course. Students from the same master will be grouped together for the seminars as much as possible, so that issues specific to these masters may be discussed or highlighted.

During both lectures, extra lectures and seminars attention will be given to current developments in competition law, possible criticism on the theoretical framework and application of competition law and the influence of economics on legal concepts of competition law. With that, the course takes a multi-dimensional approach to competition law. Open office hours of the lecturers involved will be announced. The course European competition law is relevant both for students who are interested in European law and for students who, after completing their studies, intend to work for companies or (large) law firms.
Place of this course within the curriculum:
Compulsory course in the master Law and Economics
Compulsary course in the specialisation 'International Business'
Compulsory course in the specialisation 'European Law'

column4: At the end of the course students should have gained:

column5: knowledge of regional development in Europe and the way in which this is subject of policy-making on the level of states, regions and the EU;
insight in the functioning of organisations and actors on several levels within the European arena on behalf of local and regional interest;
experience in analysing, reporting and discussing EU policy within the scope of distinct scales and geographical diversity.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The EU is as good as dead, according to some authors. They focus on the revival of nationalism and the rise of populism in Europe. The worldwide economic crisis that started in 2008 is another challenging development. We witnessed a major financial crisis in the EU, and the almost collapse of the Eurozone. A major divide has become visible (again): between the Northern and the Southern part of the EU, as it is called in the press. But perhaps there is another reason for the current EU crisis: its enormous (geographical) diversity. Many say that a monetary union is not possible without a political union. But a stronger political union would mean further integration, meaning that member states should give up more sovereignty and hand over power to Brussels.

The EU is therefore at a crossroad. How have we reached this point, and what are the further possible steps: that’s the mean focus of our course. But we will always relate European integration to the geography and the diversity of Europe. There are many geographical dimensions of the Integration Process in general, therefore, apart from the Euro-crisis, we will focus on the following questions:

column2: • What was the effect of European integration on regional differentiation in the EU? Is EU membership in general ‘good’ for economic and regional development?
• What are the causes of the eurocrisis?
• How to deal with migration and asylum seekers?
• What effect will the change of the CAP have on regional development?
• What was/is the effect of European integration on cultural diversity in the EU? Does it lead to more homogeneity or is it an impulse for cultural (national/regional) identity?

column1: During the course we try to explain the backgrounds of all these problems and dimensions, and will discuss the future of European Integration. During the first part of this course we will have lectures and an exam; during the second half we will have several debates about the future of EU policy.
For final information about modes of instruction, assessment and literature: see course manual.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: understand the many diversities existing in Europe and explain the speed, levels of and obstacles to integration in Europe in light of existing diversities;
discuss the effects of the European integration policies on European places, regions and countries;
explain how European economic, political, and cultural geographies affect the ongoing European integration process.
differentiate levels, actors and ideas that influence European Union politics and continued European integration

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course counts as a POL and GEO track finisher.

The objectives of this course are threefold-fold. First, it explores ongoing European integration in the light of the existing diversities and disparities within Europe and addresses questions pertaining to territories and borders, communities and differences, security and threat. In this context the course emphasizes topics such as labor mobility, immigration, population issues, social cohesion and external relations.  Second, the course investigates the role EU policies have played in the economic, political, and cultural transformation of contemporary Europe and its immediate neighbourhood.  Here, the course focuses in particular on changes at the regional but also country level.  Third, the course distinguishes between local, national and global pressures and its impact on the direction and speed of the European integration process.  For example, it analyzes how national or regional interests but also ideas about what Europe is or who is a European influence political debates and policy-making.

The course meets for twice a week for lectures, presentations and discussions.  Students prepare to participate actively in class by completing assigned readings . They prepare and present individual and group assignments. There is also a mid-term and a final exam.

the student has acquired a profound knowledge and understanding of the areas of freedom of movement of workers and posting and their effects on national legislations.
the student has acquired a profound knowledge and understanding of substantive European labour law in the fields of non-discrimination in the workplace and the restructuring of enterprises.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Since the EU is striving for a ‘social market economy’, it is highly relevant to have a profound insight and understanding of  the social dimension of EU law and policies and the instruments to realize them. After all, the support of the national public for the EU is highly dependent on its social dimension.

We will discuss the institutional aspects of social policy including the powers and competences of the EU in this respect, the available instruments and the particular involvement of the actors in the field (employers and workers)  in standard setting procedures (‘social dialogue’).

The course will subsequently address the free movement of workers and persons, in relation to values and effects for workers and citizens. This part will build on the prior course “Regulating the EU’s Single Market”.  In this context also posting will be dealt with, one of the most controversial topics of the present day EU.  EU Citizenship is a concept that is in particular relevant in relation to social rights, and will be dealt with in this context.

Finally, other major subjects of substantive European labour law will be addressed such as equal treatment in the workplace (on ground of age, part time work and fixed-term contracts))  and the restructuring of enterprises. The latter comprises the EU social regulation to counterbalance economic freedoms in the case of collective dismissals and transfer of undertakings.
Place of this course within the curriculum:

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course European Law offers students an insight into both important institutional questions of European Law and the general legal system of European Substantive Law, i.e. the judicial norms and regulations on the free movement of goods, workers, persons and services and harmonisation and coordination of national legislation. The course is taught in period 2 and in period 4. In period 2 the course will focus on the correction of the internal market mechanisms in view of a social market model. In period 4 the course will focus on competition law. In both periods the general part of the course will be the same.

The general part of the course covers the general system of European Law and the interaction between the internal market and other policy areas. While studying the rules on free movement the focus is on the influence of European Law on national law (“top down approach”), the economic system of the Treaties, the provisions on the four freedoms and legal protection. In addition, the European Institutions involved in the integration process will be discussed. Furthermore, the objective of harmonisation, legal bases and instruments of harmonisation, the implementation of EU directives into national law, direct effect and the relationship between harmonisation and the Treaty rules on free movement will be discussed.

In period 2, the more specific part deals with the instruments of economic and social cohesion and European employment law. It concerns the subjects of non-discrimination, cross border posting of workers in the European labour market and the restructuring of European enterprises (European procedures of redundancies, legal transfer of companies).

In period 4, the more specific part deals with competition law. We will study the general system of EU competition rules, formal competition law, i.e. the enforcement of the EU competition rules, the role of the European Commission therein, the procedures and problems of legal protection, and substantive competition law, i.e. cartels, abuse of a dominant position, merger control and state aid.
Place of this course within the curriculum:

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Do you want to give your CV a unique flavour that can open the doors of the best international law firms?

If yes, then the European Law Moot Court competition (hereafter: ELMC) is for you! The ELMC is aimed at all Master students with sufficient knowledge of European Law, English and some knowledge of French (however this condition is not exclusive). Every year in September, a case involving a fictitious Member State of the European Union and concerning issues of interpretation of EU law is published on the website of the ELMC association http://www.europeanlawmootcourt.eu/. At the end of the case several preliminary questions are referred to the Court of Justice of the European Union. The department of European Law selects a team of five students maximum who wish to participate in the competition. The selection takes place at the beginning of September. The selecting committee consists of professors of the European Law Department (Sybe de Vries and Tony Marguery). The criteria for the selection includes knowledge of EU law, capacity to work in an International environment, capacity to work under very tight deadlines and capacity to work both in English and French.

From September until the end of November, the team will analyze the case and answer the questions, in order to submit two written pleadings, one for the applicant and one for the defendant, at the end of November. The team of Utrecht University will compete with more than 80 teams from all over the world. The submissions will be reviewed by professional lawyers and the results will be announced mid-January. Only the best pleadings (only 48 teams in general) are selected to continue to the next stage of the competition: the oral rounds (or regional finals). The selected teams will meet and moot at four different universities across Europe and the United States, in February/March. The four teams who won the regional finals will eventually compete in the ELMC final at the Court of Justice in Luxembourg in April.

This international Moot Court competition is a great opportunity to increase your knowledge of European Union Law and to share your Legal skills with other students. It is a unique chance to meet and compete with students from all over the world!

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172331,2016,European Union Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['A. Minto'],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Please note the prerequisites for this course, you are expected to have knowledge of certain courses.

The course “European Union Law” aims to provide insight and knowledge into the basic legal principles, legal institutions and the impact of European Union Law. The principle aim of this course is to help students to achieve a critical and informed understanding of the way in which European Union law operates. It offers a general overview of the core principles of the treaties of the EU, secondary legislation and case law.

The course builds on two themes: institutional law, which provides insight in the actors within the European Union, the decision making processes and judicial protection in the European Union, and substantive law, which will be discussed on the basis of internal market law, and even beyond internal market law, on the basis of European Union citizenship.

The institutional part of the course will analyse some of the constitutional principles which form the base of the European Union and play an important role in the division of competences between the European Union and its Member Sates. Besides, rules concerning the effects of EU law within the national systems will be discussed.

With regard to the second part of the course, in order to achieve the internal market, the Member States of the European Union have decided to share some competence to regulate the free movement of goods, economic active persons, services and capital. Economic activities in these Member States (and also outside the Union) are therefore considerably affected by the internal market. The purpose of this part of the course is to introduce the most important mechanisms concerning this phenomenon in order to determine to what extent the Member States government remain free to regulate the relation between producers and consumers.

Specific aspects of the institutional law of the EU (relating for example to the protection of fundamental rights in the EU legal order) or internal market (relating for example to the regulation of the energy, environment, telecommunication or tax sectors) may be addressed during weekly seminars for which students will have to write and present an essay. Development in both major themes will be discussed in an economic, political and societal context.

The student gains a thorough understanding into questions as: ‘What are the reasons for the historical development of the European Union?’; ‘Who are the important actors in the decision making-process and how do these practices work in practices?’; ‘How does the internal market work and how does it affect political and societal differences within the Member States’ and ‘How can we evaluate internal market regulation?’. The course builds on a multidisciplinary approach (including economic theory, historical context and political philosophy), but provides a primarily legal understanding of the theories and rules governing European Union Legislation.
Topics to be dealt with include:
-          Introduction: general aspects of EU law, structure of the EU;
-          EU institutions and decision-making processes and legal instruments;
-          Supremacy, direct effect of EU law, reception of EU law and state liability;
-          Judicial protection: how to enforce EU law?
-         Internal market I: introduction to free movement principles, free movement of goods;
-         Internal market II: free movement of services and persons;
-         Internal market III: European Union citizenship;
-         Internal market IV: the free movement of capital and introduction to competition law.
Synthesis: government regulation and economic and practical reality.

column2: • Has a general overview of the core principles of the European Union legal system;
• Has knowledge and understanding of EU law, both institutional and substantive;
• Comprehends the importance of the law of the EU for economics;
• Is able to perform a small research on a topic related to the course and answer a specific question in this regard;
• Is able to present arguments and the results of his research in writing;
• Is able to present orally the outcome of his/her research in English;
• Is able to lead a discussion in the class on the topic of the essay presented;
• Has developed a vision on the broader economic, political and societal context of European Union law.

column1: Lectures, tutorials and seminars, including discussion-tutorials and case-questions, presentation of essays during seminars.

Attendance to the weekly lecture is not compulsory. By contrast, students are obliged to attend 80% of the weekly tutorials and seminars, and should participate actively in class discussions. In order to do so, students are expected to study in detail the mandatory literature for each week in advance. It is expected that students bring their text of the Treaty with them to each seminar and tutorial. For each seminar the answers to the seminar questions of several students will be randomly collected for review (however, no grade will be given by the teacher, only feedback).

Besides, the students will have to write a small essay (1000 to 1500 words) on one of the topics discussed in class. This assignment implies also that students do some research on their own in specific fields of EU law. The purpose of the essay is to focus on one question, a thesis, and use the essay to answer the question. Students will present these essays during weekly seminars.
Place of the course within the curriculum
The course is part of the Law Minor of U.S.E. The course is only open to U.S.E. students. Students must have followed the course Introduction to Law (ECB1IL) in order to apply for this course.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Since the impact of European law on the daily lives of citizens has increased, knowledge of this field has become important for practitioners engaged in a wide range of professional activities. This course provides students with the necessary knowledge and skills to understand the extent of this impact. It begins with a critical overview of the legal system of the European Union: its origin, the evolution of its legal rules, the legal construct of economic freedoms, and European integration.

Subjects include: the Internal Market and European competition law, the legal foundations of the European Union; the institutions of the European Union and their decision-making competence; the sources of the law of the European Union; the relationship between the legal system of the European Union and those of member States; and the enforcement of European Union law at the European and national level. The sessions on economic law introduce the four freedoms and competition law on which the internal market is based and the way in which these policies are affected through Community law and upheld by the European Court of Justice.

column3: The first part of the course is structured on the basis of a lecture/seminar set up. The instructor introduces main issues each week in an interactive lecture, whereas seminars are meant to further discuss legal issues more in-depth on the basis of seminar questions and cases. This part of the course is concluded by an exam in the first week of November.

During the second part of the course, each student is part of two small groups (3-4 students). The first group is the research clinic group. Each group is assigned a researcher studying a particular EU related issue. The group then acts as host for their researcher-of-the-day, presents the research and leads the class discussion. The second group each student is part of is the moot court group. Students participate in a moot court simulation that consists of a written and an oral part.</body>

column4: After completing this course students have:

column5: knowledge and understanding of European politics, and decision-making procedures at different decision-making levels;
knowledge and understanding of different theoretical perspectives on European decision-making and influence on policy;
understanding of practices of European governance by means of different specific cases;
practical applications of the readings on a selected case of European lobbying.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Ever since its origin, the European Union aimed to solve cross-border problems, and to avoid military conflict between states. With the widening of the Union from safety and economic issues to environmental, legal and social issues in the 1980s, the impact of the EU has increased dramatically. Increasingly, the EU determines the room for maneuver of the Dutch administration, Dutch business entrepreneurs and civil society. For example, the EU plays an increasingly important role in issues such as migration, health care and the financial crisis. However, the EU also has an increasingly strong impact on the lives of ordinary citizens. We pay in euros, study to become Bachelors or Masters, and are confronted with traffic policies that are directly inspired by the European environmental directives.

This course aims to give more insight into the making of European policies and its consequences for its citizens. The course will therefore use both a bottom-up and a top-down perspective, and focus on the forces that speed up or slow down European integration, the formal and informal procedures by which European policy is made, and the effects of European decision-making for politics, society and citizens. The course will use theoretical perspectives from public administration and political science. The knowledge gained from these insights will be assessed by means of a written exam.
In addition, you will work intensively on a number of recent cases of European governance to gain more understanding in its actual processes. Special attention will be paid to (amongst other things):

column2: • The role of the EU in the current financial crisis;
• The relation between the EU and its citizens;
• Enlargement of the EU (Turkey) and its consequences;
• What are the formal and informal venues for lobbying? What is the most effective strategy to influence decision-making on this issue?

• Theoretical and practical insights will come together in a paper that you write on a case of lobbying in Europe; a case selected by yourself by either a civil society actor or governmental actor. Questions addressed in the paper include: how does EU decision-making work in this issue-area?

column1: Please note that for non-USG bachelor students the course Introduction public administration and organizational science (USG5520/USG5020) or another introductional course covering the subject of public administration is recommended.
30. Places will be allocated in order of subscription. If less than 10 students subscribe, the course may not be made available. </body>
